fitk.graphics

Submodule for plotting of Fisher objects. See here for documentation of FisherFigure1D, FisherFigure2D, and FisherBarFigure.

  51@dataclass
  52class _TempContainer:
  53    labels: Sequence[str]
  54    colors: Sequence[str]

  62class _FisherBaseFigure:
  63    def __init__(
  64        self,
  65        options: Optional[dict] = None,
  66        **kwargs,
  67    ):
  68        """
  69        Constructor
  70        """
  71        self._figure = None
  72        self._axes: Optional[Union[Axes, Sequence[Axes]]] = None
  73        self._handles: MutableSequence[Artist] = []
  74        self._labels: MutableSequence[str] = []
  75        self._options: dict = get_default_rcparams()
  76
  77        self.cycler = plt.rcParams["axes.prop_cycle"].by_key()["color"]
  78        self.current_color = iter(self.cycler)
  79
  80        if options and "style" in options:
  81            style = options.pop("style")
  82            # maybe it's one of the built-in styles
  83            if style in plt.style.available:
  84                self._options = {
  85                    **plt.style.library[style],
  86                    **get_default_rcparams(),
  87                    **options,
  88                }
  89                # we need to reset the color cycler
  90                self.cycler = (
  91                    plt.style.library[style]
  92                    .get(
  93                        "axes.prop_cycle",
  94                        plt.rcParams["axes.prop_cycle"],
  95                    )
  96                    .by_key()["color"]
  97                )
  98                self.current_color = iter(self.cycler)
  99
 100            # maybe it's a file
 101            else:
 102                # we need to reset the color cycler
 103                self.cycler = (
 104                    plt.style.core.rc_params_from_file(style)
 105                    .get(
 106                        "axes.prop_cycle",
 107                        plt.rcParams["axes.prop_cycle"],
 108                    )
 109                    .by_key()["color"]
 110                )
 111                self.current_color = iter(self.cycler)
 112
 113                self._options = {
 114                    **plt.style.core.rc_params_from_file(style),
 115                    **options,
 116                }
 117
 118    @property
 119    def options(self):
 120        """
 121        Returns the matplotlib options which were used for plotting.
 122        """
 123        return self._options
 124
 125    @property
 126    def axes(self):
 127        """
 128        Returns the axes of the figure as a numpy array.
 129        """
 130        return self._axes

 132    @property
 133    def figure(self):
 134        """
 135        Returns the underlying figure, an instance of <a
 136        href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/figure_api.html#matplotlib.figure.Figure"
 137        target="_blank" rel="noreferrer
 138        noopener">`matplotlib.figure.Figure`</a>.
 139        """
 140        return self._figure

 142    @property

 145        Returns the handles of the currently drawn artists.

 156    def savefig(
 157        self,
 158        path: Union[str, Path],
 159        dpi: float = 300,
 160        bbox_inches: Union[str, Bbox] = "tight",
 161        **kwargs,
 162    ):
 163        """
 164        Convenience wrapper for <a
 165        href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/figure_api.html#matplotlib.figure.Figure.savefig"
 166        target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">`figure.savefig`</a>.
 167
 168        Parameters
 169        ----------
 170        path : Path or str
 171            the path where to save the figure
 172
 173        dpi : float, optional
 174            the resolution of the saved figure (default: 300)
 175
 176        bbox_inches : str or Bbox, optional
 177            what is the bounding box for the figure (default: 'tight')
 178
 179        **kwargs
 180            any other keyword arguments that should be passed to
 181            `figure.savefig`
 182
 183        Returns
 184        -------
 185        None
 186
 187        Raises
 188        ------
 189        EmptyFigureError
 190            if `figure` is not set
 191        """
 192        if not self.figure:
 193            raise EmptyFigureError
 194
 195        self.figure.savefig(
 196            path,
 197            dpi=dpi,
 198            bbox_inches=bbox_inches,
 199            **kwargs,
 200        )

 203class EmptyFigureError(Exception):
 204    """
 205    Error raised when the figure is empty
 206    """
 207
 208    def __init__(self):
 209        self.message = (
 210            "The figure is empty; make sure to call one of the plotting methods before"
 211        )
 212        super().__init__(self.message)

 215class _FisherMultipleAxesFigure(_FisherBaseFigure, ABC):
 216    """
 217    The abstract base class for plotting Fisher objects.
 218    """
 219
 220    def __init__(
 221        self,
 222        *args,
 223        options: Optional[dict] = None,
 224        hspace: float = 0.1,
 225        wspace: float = 0.1,
 226        contour_levels: Optional[Sequence[tuple[float, float]]] = None,
 227        **kwargs,
 228    ):
 229        """
 230        Constructor
 231        """
 232        self._names = None
 233        self._options: dict = {}
 234        self._ndim: int = 0
 235        self._hspace = hspace
 236        self._wspace = wspace
 237
 238        super().__init__(options=options, **kwargs)
 239
 240        # parse `contour_levels`
 241        if contour_levels is None:
 242            self.contour_levels = [(1.0, 0.3), (2.0, 0.1)]
 243        else:
 244            try:
 245                contour_levels = [
 246                    (float(level), float(alpha)) for level, alpha in contour_levels
 247                ]
 248            except Exception as exc:
 249                raise ValueError(
 250                    f"The object {contour_levels} cannot be converted to a list of 2-tuples"
 251                ) from exc
 252            for level, alpha in contour_levels:
 253                if level < 0:
 254                    raise ValueError(
 255                        f"Negative contour level found in: {contour_levels}"
 256                    )
 257                if not 0 <= alpha <= 1:
 258                    raise ValueError(
 259                        f"Opacity value outside of (0, 1) found in: {contour_levels}"
 260                    )
 261            self.contour_levels = contour_levels
 262
 263    @abstractmethod
 264    def plot(self, fisher: FisherMatrix, *args, **kwargs):
 265        """
 266        Implements plotting of Fisher objects.
 267        """
 268        return NotImplemented
 269
 270    @abstractmethod
 271    def __getitem__(self, key):
 272        """
 273        Implements element access.
 274        """
 275        return NotImplemented
 276
 277    @property
 278    def hspace(self) -> float:
 279        """
 280        The amount of height reserved for space between subplots, expressed as
 281        a fraction of the average axis height.
 282        """
 283        return self._hspace
 284
 285    @property
 286    def wspace(self) -> float:
 287        """
 288        The amount of width reserved for space between subplots, expressed as a
 289        fraction of the average axis width.
 290        """
 291        return self._wspace
 292
 293    @property
 294    def names(self):
 295        """
 296        Returns the names of the original parameters plotted.
 297        """
 298        return self._names
 299
 300    def __repr__(self):
 301        """
 302        Returns the representation of the figure
 303        """
 304        return (
 305            f"<{self.__class__.__name__}(\n"
 306            f"    names={repr(self.names)},\n"
 307            f"    figure={repr(self.figure)},\n"
 308            f"    axes={repr(self.axes)})>"
 309        )
 310
 311    def __str__(self):
 312        """
 313        Returns the string representation of the figure
 314        """
 315        return (
 316            f"{self.__class__.__name__}(\n"
 317            f"    names={str(self.names)},\n"
 318            f"    figure={str(self.figure)},\n"
 319            f"    axes={str(self.axes)})"
 320        )

 322    def add_artist_to_legend(
 323        self,
 324        artist: Artist,
 325        label: str,
 326    ):
 327        r"""
 328        This is a convenience function for correctly updating the legend after
 329        directly plotting some artist via `<instance>[<name(s)>].<method>`
 330
 331        Parameters
 332        ----------
 333        artist
 334            the artist which we want to put on the legend
 335
 336        label : str
 337            the label for the artist
 338
 339        Returns
 340        -------
 341        None
 342
 343        Examples
 344        --------
 345        Setup the plot:
 346        >>> fig = FisherFigure1D()
 347        >>> fig.plot(FisherMatrix(np.diag([1, 2]), names=["a", "b"]), label="Fisher matrix")
 348
 349        Add something to the plot that has a handle:
 350        >>> handle, = fig["a"].plot([-1, 0, 1], [-1, 0, 1], color='red')
 351
 352        Finally, add the handle to the legend, and draw the legend:
 353        >>> fig.add_artist_to_legend(handle, "linear function")
 354        >>> _ = fig.legend() # the artist will now be shown correctly in the legend
 355
 356        Save it to a file:
 357        >>> fig.savefig(
 358        ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure2d_add_artist_to_legend1.png",
 359        ... dpi=150)
 360
 361        <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure2d_add_artist_to_legend1.png">
 362
 363        Notes
 364        -----
 365        The limits of the plot are not updated automatically.
 366        """
 367        self.labels.append(label)
 368        self.handles.append(artist)
 369
 370    def set_label_params(
 371        self,
 372        which: str = "both",
 373        **kwargs,
 374    ):
 375        """
 376        Collectively sets both x and y label parameters.
 377
 378        Parameters
 379        ----------
 380        which : {'both', 'x', 'y'}
 381            which axis to change (default: 'both')
 382
 383        **kwargs
 384            any keyword arguments that are also valid for
 385            `matplotlib.text.Text`, see <a
 386            href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/text_api.html#matplotlib.text.Text"
 387            target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">the matplotlib
 388            documentation</a> for details
 389
 390        Returns
 391        -------
 392        None
 393
 394        Raises
 395        ------
 396        EmptyFigureError
 397            if `figure` is not set
 398        """
 399        if not self.figure:
 400            raise EmptyFigureError
 401
 402        for nameiter in product(self.names, repeat=self._ndim):
 403            # only set the parameters which are not empty (should this be done
 404            # for all of them instead?)
 405            if (
 406                self[nameiter]
 407                and self[nameiter].get_xlabel()
 408                and which in ["both", "x"]
 409            ):
 410                self[nameiter].set_xlabel(
 411                    self[nameiter].get_xlabel(),
 412                    **kwargs,
 413                )
 414            if (
 415                self[nameiter]
 416                and self[nameiter].get_ylabel()
 417                and which in ["both", "y"]
 418            ):
 419                self[nameiter].set_ylabel(
 420                    self[nameiter].get_ylabel(),
 421                    **kwargs,
 422                )
 423
 424    def set_tick_params(
 425        self,
 426        which: str = "both",
 427        **kwargs,
 428    ):
 429        """
 430        Collectively sets both x and y tick parameters.
 431
 432        Parameters
 433        ----------
 434        which : {'both', 'x', 'y'}
 435            which axis to change (default: 'both')
 436
 437        **kwargs
 438            any keyword arguments passed to the methods for handling tick
 439            parameters (such as 'fontsize', 'rotation', etc.)
 440
 441        Returns
 442        -------
 443        None
 444
 445        Raises
 446        ------
 447        EmptyFigureError
 448            if `figure` is not set
 449        """
 450        if not self.figure:
 451            raise EmptyFigureError
 452
 453        for nameiter in product(self.names, repeat=self._ndim):
 454            if self[nameiter] and which in ["both", "x"]:
 455                for item in self[nameiter].get_xticklabels():
 456                    for key, value in kwargs.items():
 457                        getattr(item, f"set_{key}")(value)
 458            if self[nameiter] and which in ["both", "y"]:
 459                for item in self[nameiter].get_yticklabels():
 460                    for key, value in kwargs.items():
 461                        getattr(item, f"set_{key}")(value)
 462            # also alter any exponential offsets
 463            for key, value in kwargs.items():
 464                if self[nameiter] and which in ["both", "x"]:
 465                    getattr(
 466                        self[nameiter].get_xaxis().get_offset_text(),
 467                        f"set_{key}",
 468                    )(value)
 469                if self[nameiter] and which in ["both", "y"]:
 470                    getattr(
 471                        self[nameiter].get_yaxis().get_offset_text(),
 472                        f"set_{key}",
 473                    )(value)
 474
 475    def set_major_locator(
 476        self,
 477        locator: Locator,
 478        which: str = "both",
 479    ):
 480        """
 481        Sets the major locator for all of the axes.
 482
 483        Parameters
 484        ----------
 485        locator
 486            the instance of `matplotlib.ticker.Locator` to use.
 487
 488        which : {'both', 'x', 'y'}
 489            which axis to change (default: 'both')
 490
 491        Returns
 492        -------
 493        None
 494
 495        Raises
 496        ------
 497        EmptyFigureError
 498            if `figure` is not set
 499        """
 500        if not self.figure:
 501            raise EmptyFigureError
 502
 503        for nameiter in product(self.names, repeat=self._ndim):
 504            # for some reason, we cannot reuse the same instance, so we just
 505            # make a deep copy of it instead
 506            if (
 507                self[nameiter]
 508                and np.any(self[nameiter].get_xticks())
 509                and which in ["both", "x"]
 510            ):
 511                xloc = copy.deepcopy(locator)
 512                self[nameiter].xaxis.set_major_locator(xloc)
 513            if (
 514                self[nameiter]
 515                and np.any(self[nameiter].get_yticks())
 516                and which in ["both", "y"]
 517            ):
 518                yloc = copy.deepcopy(locator)
 519                self[nameiter].yaxis.set_major_locator(yloc)
 520
 521    def set_minor_locator(
 522        self,
 523        locator: Locator,
 524        which: str = "both",
 525    ):
 526        """
 527        Sets the minor locator for all of the axes.
 528
 529        Parameters
 530        ----------
 531        locator
 532            the instance of `matplotlib.ticker.Locator` to use.
 533
 534        which : {'both', 'x', 'y'}
 535            which axis to change (default: 'both')
 536
 537        Returns
 538        -------
 539        None
 540
 541        Raises
 542        ------
 543        EmptyFigureError
 544            if `figure` is not set
 545        """
 546        if not self.figure:
 547            raise EmptyFigureError
 548
 549        for nameiter in product(self.names, repeat=self._ndim):
 550            if (
 551                self[nameiter]
 552                and np.any(self[nameiter].get_xticks())
 553                and which in ["both", "x"]
 554            ):
 555                # same reason as the major locator
 556                xloc = copy.deepcopy(locator)
 557                self[nameiter].xaxis.set_minor_locator(xloc)
 558            if (
 559                self[nameiter]
 560                and np.any(self[nameiter].get_yticks())
 561                and which in ["both", "y"]
 562            ):
 563                yloc = copy.deepcopy(locator)
 564                self[nameiter].yaxis.set_minor_locator(yloc)
 565

 634
 635class FisherBarFigure(_FisherBaseFigure):
 636    """
 637    Container for plotting single-axis bar-like figures
 638    (`plot_absolute_constraints` and `plot_relative_constraints`)
 639    """
 640
 641    def _parse_fractional_constraints(
 642        self,
 643        args: Sequence[FisherMatrix],
 644        marginalized: bool = True,
 645        colors: Optional[Sequence[str]] = None,
 646        labels: Optional[Sequence[str]] = None,
 647        values_label: Optional[str] = None,
 648        percent: bool = False,
 649        space: float = 0.3,
 650        scale: str = "linear",
 651    ):
 652        # error handling
 653        if not 0 <= space <= 1:
 654            raise ValueError("The value of `space` must be in the open interval (0, 1)")
 655
 656        allowed_scales = ["linear", "log", "symlog"]
 657        if scale not in allowed_scales:
 658            raise ValueError(f"The value of `scale` must be one of: {allowed_scales}")
 659
 660        for arg in args:
 661            if set(args[0].names) != set(arg.names):
 662                raise MismatchingValuesError(
 663                    "parameter name",
 664                    args[0].names,
 665                    arg.names,
 666                )
 667
 668        # total number of parameters in the Fisher objects
 669        size = len(args[0])
 670
 671        # the width or height of all columns for a single parameter
 672        total_space = 1 - space
 673
 674        # the width or height of a single column for a single parameter
 675        space_per_object = total_space / len(args)
 676
 677        if not colors:
 678            colors = list(islice(self.current_color, len(args)))  # type: ignore
 679        elif len(colors) != len(args):
 680            raise MismatchingSizeError(colors, args)
 681
 682        if not labels:
 683            labels = [""] * len(args)
 684        elif len(labels) != len(args):
 685            raise MismatchingSizeError(labels, args)
 686
 687        if not values_label:
 688            if percent:
 689                values_label = r"$\sigma / \theta_\mathrm{fid}\ (\%)$"
 690            else:
 691                values_label = r"$\sigma / \theta_\mathrm{fid}$"
 692
 693        return _TempContainer(
 694            labels,
 695            colors,  # type: ignore
 696            [
 697                [
 698                    _ - total_space / 2 + (2 * index + 1) * space_per_object / 2
 699                    for _ in range(size)
 700                ]
 701                for index, arg in enumerate(args)
 702            ],
 703            [
 704                np.array(
 705                    [
 706                        arg.constraints(name=_, marginalized=marginalized)[0]
 707                        for _ in arg.names
 708                    ]
 709                )
 710                / np.array(
 711                    [
 712                        np.abs(fid) if not np.isclose(fid, 0) else 1
 713                        for fid in arg.fiducials
 714                    ]
 715                )
 716                for index, arg in enumerate(args)
 717            ],
 718            space_per_object=space_per_object,
 719            values_label=values_label,
 720            scale=scale,
 721        )
 722
 723    def plot_absolute_constraints(
 724        self,
 725        args: Sequence[FisherMatrix],
 726        kind: str,
 727        marginalized: bool = True,
 728        colors: Optional[Sequence[str]] = None,
 729        labels: Optional[Sequence[str]] = None,
 730        values_label: Optional[str] = None,
 731        scale: str = "linear",
 732        space: float = 0.3,
 733        capsize: Optional[float] = None,
 734        **kwargs,
 735    ):
 736        r"""
 737        Makes a plot of the constraints of the Fisher matrices
 738
 739        Parameters
 740        ----------
 741        args : array_like of FisherMatrix
 742            the Fisher matrices for which we want to plot the constraints
 743
 744        kind : str, {'bar', 'barh', 'errorbar'}
 745            the kind of plot we want (vertical bar, horizontal bar, errorbar)
 746
 747        marginalized : bool, optional
 748            whether the marginalized or the unmarginalized constraints should
 749            be plotted (default: True)
 750
 751        colors : array_like of str, optional
 752            the colors to use for the plotting (default: default matplotlib
 753            colors)
 754
 755        labels : array_like of str, optional
 756            the labels for the Fisher matrices (default: None)
 757
 758        values_label : str, optional
 759            the label for the axis containing the constraints (default:
 760            `$\theta_\mathrm{fid}$`)
 761
 762        scale : str, {'linear', 'log'}
 763            the scale used for the y axis (default: 'linear')
 764
 765        space : float, optional
 766            the space reserved between the bars (default: 0.3)
 767
 768        capsize : float, optional
 769            the width of the errorbars (default: none, that is, determined
 770            automatically)
 771
 772        **kwargs
 773            any keyword arguments passed to <a
 774            href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.bar.html"
 775            target="_blank" rel=noreferrer
 776            noopener>`matplotlib.pyplot.bar`</a>, or <a
 777            href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.barh.html"
 778            target="_blank" rel=noreferrer
 779            noopener>`matplotlib.pyplot.barh`</a>, or <a
 780            href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.errorbar.html"
 781            target="_blank" rel=noreferrer
 782            noopener>`matplotlib.pyplot.errorbar`</a>.
 783        Returns
 784        -------
 785        None
 786
 787        Examples
 788        --------
 789        Define some Fisher matrices:
 790        >>> fm1 = FisherMatrix(np.diag([1, 2, 3]) * 1e3, names=["a", "b", "c"], latex_names=[r'$\Omega_\mathrm{m}$', '$h$', "$n_s$"], fiducials=[0.3, 0.7, 0.96])
 791        >>> fm2 = FisherMatrix(np.diag([4, 5, 6]) * 1e3, names=["a", "b", "c"], latex_names=[r'$\Omega_\mathrm{m}$', '$h$', "$n_s$"], fiducials=[0.35, 0.67, 0.9])
 792
 793        Make a vertical bar plot:
 794        >>> fig = FisherBarFigure()
 795        >>> fig.plot_absolute_constraints([fm1, fm2], 'bar', labels=['Fisher 1', 'Fisher 2'])
 796        >>> _ = fig.figure.legend()
 797
 798        Save it to a file:
 799        >>> fig.savefig(
 800        ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure_plot_absolute_constraints_bar.png",
 801        ... dpi=150)
 802
 803        <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure_plot_absolute_constraints_bar.png">
 804
 805        Make a horizontal bar plot:
 806        >>> fig = FisherBarFigure()
 807        >>> fig.plot_absolute_constraints([fm1, fm2], 'barh', labels=['Fisher 1', 'Fisher 2'])
 808        >>> _ = fig.figure.legend()
 809
 810        Save it to a file:
 811        >>> fig.savefig(
 812        ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure_plot_absolute_constraints_barh.png",
 813        ... dpi=150)
 814
 815        <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure_plot_absolute_constraints_barh.png">
 816
 817        Make an errobar plot:
 818        >>> fig = FisherBarFigure()
 819        >>> fig.plot_absolute_constraints([fm1, fm2], 'errorbar', labels=['Fisher 1', 'Fisher 2'], capsize=4)
 820        >>> _ = fig.figure.legend()
 821
 822        Save it to a file:
 823        >>> fig.savefig(
 824        ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure_plot_absolute_constraints_errorbar.png",
 825        ... dpi=150)
 826
 827        <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure_plot_absolute_constraints_errorbar.png">
 828        """
 829        size = len(args[0])
 830        latex_names = args[0].latex_names
 831
 832        # error handling
 833        if not 0 <= space <= 1:
 834            raise ValueError("The value of `space` must be in the open interval (0, 1)")
 835
 836        allowed_scales = ["linear", "log"]
 837        if scale not in allowed_scales:
 838            raise ValueError(f"The value of `scale` must be one of: {allowed_scales}")
 839
 840        for arg in args:
 841            if set(args[0].names) != set(arg.names):
 842                raise MismatchingValuesError(
 843                    "parameter name",
 844                    args[0].names,
 845                    arg.names,
 846                )
 847
 848        # the width or height of all columns for a single parameter
 849        total_space = 1 - space
 850
 851        # the width or height of a single column for a single parameter
 852        space_per_object = total_space / len(args)
 853
 854        if not colors:
 855            colors = list(islice(self.current_color, len(args)))  # type: ignore
 856        elif len(colors) != len(args):
 857            raise MismatchingSizeError(colors, args)
 858
 859        if not labels:
 860            labels = [""] * len(args)
 861        elif len(labels) != len(args):
 862            raise MismatchingSizeError(labels, args)
 863
 864        if not values_label:
 865            values_label = r"$\theta_\mathrm{fid}$"
 866
 867        x_array = [
 868            [
 869                _ - total_space / 2 + (2 * index + 1) * space_per_object / 2
 870                for _ in range(size)
 871            ]
 872            for index, arg in enumerate(args)
 873        ]
 874        y_array = [arg.fiducials for arg in args]
 875        yerr_array = [
 876            np.array(
 877                [
 878                    arg.constraints(name=_, marginalized=marginalized)[0]
 879                    for _ in arg.names
 880                ]
 881            )
 882            for index, arg in enumerate(args)
 883        ]
 884
 885        # TODO: maybe put this in a class so validation is easier
 886        options = {
 887            "bar": {
 888                "parameters_scale": "x",
 889                "values_scale": "y",
 890                "error_name": "yerr",
 891                "extra_kwargs": {
 892                    "capsize": total_space * 60 / len(args) / size,
 893                    "width": space_per_object,
 894                },
 895            },
 896            "barh": {
 897                "parameters_scale": "y",
 898                "values_scale": "x",
 899                "error_name": "xerr",
 900                "extra_kwargs": {
 901                    "capsize": total_space * 60 / len(args) / size,
 902                    "height": space_per_object,
 903                },
 904            },
 905            "errorbar": {
 906                "parameters_scale": "x",
 907                "values_scale": "y",
 908                "error_name": "yerr",
 909                "extra_kwargs": {
 910                    "capsize": total_space * 120 / len(args) / size,
 911                    "ls": kwargs.pop("ls", ""),
 912                    "marker": kwargs.pop("marker", "o"),
 913                },
 914            },
 915        }
 916
 917        if capsize is not None:
 918            options[kind]["extra_kwargs"]["capsize"] = capsize  # type: ignore
 919
 920        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
 921            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
 922            for color, label, x, y, yerr in zip(
 923                colors,  # type: ignore
 924                labels,
 925                x_array,
 926                y_array,
 927                yerr_array,
 928            ):
 929                getattr(ax, kind)(
 930                    x,
 931                    y,
 932                    color=color,
 933                    label=label,
 934                    **{options[kind]["error_name"]: yerr},
 935                    **options[kind]["extra_kwargs"],
 936                    **kwargs,
 937                )
 938
 939            ax.set_yscale(scale)
 940
 941            getattr(ax, f'set_{options[kind]["parameters_scale"]}ticks')(range(size))
 942            getattr(ax, f'set_{options[kind]["parameters_scale"]}ticklabels')(
 943                latex_names
 944            )
 945            getattr(ax, f'set_{options[kind]["values_scale"]}label')(values_label)
 946
 947        self._figure = fig
 948        self._axes = ax
 949
 950    def plot_relative_constraints(
 951        self,
 952        args: Sequence[FisherMatrix],
 953        kind: str,
 954        marginalized: bool = True,
 955        colors: Optional[Sequence[str]] = None,
 956        labels: Optional[Sequence[str]] = None,
 957        values_label: Optional[str] = None,
 958        scale: str = "linear",
 959        space: float = 0.3,
 960        percent: bool = False,
 961        **kwargs,
 962    ):
 963        r"""
 964        Makes a plot of the constraints (relative to the fiducial) of the
 965        Fisher matrices
 966
 967        Parameters
 968        ----------
 969        args : array_like of FisherMatrix
 970            the Fisher matrices for which we want to plot the constraints
 971
 972        kind : str, {'bar', 'barh', 'errorbar'}
 973            the kind of plot we want (vertical bar, horizontal bar, errorbar)
 974
 975        marginalized : bool, optional
 976            whether the marginalized or the unmarginalized constraints should
 977            be plotted (default: True)
 978
 979        colors : array_like of str, optional
 980            the colors to use for the plotting (default: default matplotlib
 981            colors)
 982
 983        labels : array_like of str, optional
 984            the labels for the Fisher matrices (default: None)
 985
 986        values_label : str, optional
 987            the label for the values, that is, the y axis (default: `$\sigma /
 988            \theta_\mathrm{fid}$` if `percent` is false, otherwise `$\sigma /
 989            \theta_\mathrm{fid}\ (\%)$`
 990
 991        scale : str, {'linear', 'log'}
 992            the scale used for the y axis (default: 'linear')
 993
 994        space : float, optional
 995            the space reserved between the bars (default: 0.3)
 996
 997        percent : bool, optional
 998            whether to plot in percentage units (default: false)
 999
1000        **kwargs
1001            any keyword arguments passed to
1002            <a
1003            href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.bar.html"
1004            target="_blank" rel=noreferrer noopener>`matplotlib.pyplot.bar`</a>
1005
1006        Returns
1007        -------
1008        None
1009
1010        Examples
1011        --------
1012        Define some Fisher matrices:
1013        >>> fm1 = FisherMatrix(np.diag([1, 2, 3]) * 1e3, names=["a", "b", "c"], latex_names=[r'$\Omega_\mathrm{m}$', '$h$', "$n_s$"], fiducials=[0.3, 0.7, 0.96])
1014        >>> fm2 = FisherMatrix(np.diag([4, 5, 6]) * 1e3, names=["a", "b", "c"], latex_names=[r'$\Omega_\mathrm{m}$', '$h$', "$n_s$"], fiducials=[0.35, 0.67, 0.9])
1015
1016        Make a vertical bar plot:
1017        >>> fig = FisherBarFigure()
1018        >>> fig.plot_relative_constraints([fm1, fm2], 'bar', labels=['Fisher 1', 'Fisher 2'])
1019        >>> _ = fig.figure.legend()
1020
1021        Save it to a file:
1022        >>> fig.savefig(
1023        ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure_plot_relative_constraints_bar.png",
1024        ... dpi=150)
1025
1026        <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure_plot_relative_constraints_bar.png">
1027
1028        Make a horizontal bar plot:
1029        >>> fig = FisherBarFigure()
1030        >>> fig.plot_relative_constraints([fm1, fm2], 'barh', labels=['Fisher 1', 'Fisher 2'])
1031        >>> _ = fig.figure.legend()
1032
1033        Save it to a file:
1034        >>> fig.savefig(
1035        ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure_plot_relative_constraints_barh.png",
1036        ... dpi=150)
1037
1038        <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure_plot_relative_constraints_barh.png">
1039        """
1040        size = len(args[0])
1041        latex_names = args[0].latex_names
1042
1043        computed_parameters = self._parse_fractional_constraints(
1044            args,
1045            marginalized=marginalized,
1046            colors=colors,
1047            labels=labels,
1048            scale=scale,
1049            space=space,
1050            values_label=values_label,
1051            percent=percent,
1052        )
1053
1054        # TODO: maybe put this in a class so validation is easier
1055        options = {
1056            "bar": {
1057                "parameters_scale": "x",
1058                "values_scale": "y",
1059                "lines_prefix": "h",
1060                "extra_kwargs": {
1061                    "width": computed_parameters.space_per_object,
1062                },
1063            },
1064            "barh": {
1065                "parameters_scale": "y",
1066                "values_scale": "x",
1067                "lines_prefix": "v",
1068                "extra_kwargs": {
1069                    "height": computed_parameters.space_per_object,
1070                },
1071            },
1072        }
1073
1074        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1075            fig, ax = plt.subplots()
1076            for color, label, x, y in zip(
1077                computed_parameters.colors,
1078                computed_parameters.labels,
1079                computed_parameters.x_array,
1080                computed_parameters.y_array,
1081            ):
1082                getattr(ax, kind)(
1083                    x,
1084                    y * 100 if percent else y,
1085                    color=color,
1086                    label=label,
1087                    **options[kind]["extra_kwargs"],
1088                    **kwargs,
1089                )
1090                getattr(ax, kind)(
1091                    x,
1092                    -(y * 100 if percent else y),
1093                    color=color,
1094                    label=None,
1095                    **options[kind]["extra_kwargs"],
1096                    **kwargs,
1097                )
1098
1099            limits = getattr(ax, f'get_{options[kind]["parameters_scale"]}lim')()
1100
1101            getattr(ax, f'{options[kind]["lines_prefix"]}lines')(
1102                0, limits[0], limits[-1], color="black", ls="--"
1103            )
1104            getattr(ax, f'set_{options[kind]["parameters_scale"]}lim')(*limits)
1105            getattr(ax, f'set_{options[kind]["values_scale"]}scale')(
1106                computed_parameters.scale
1107            )
1108
1109            getattr(ax, f'set_{options[kind]["parameters_scale"]}ticks')(range(size))
1110            getattr(ax, f'set_{options[kind]["parameters_scale"]}ticklabels')(
1111                latex_names
1112            )
1113            getattr(ax, f'set_{options[kind]["values_scale"]}label')(
1114                computed_parameters.values_label
1115            )
1116
1117        self._figure = fig
1118        self._axes = ax
1119
1120
1121class FisherFigure1D(_FisherMultipleAxesFigure):
1122    r"""
1123    Container for easy access to elements in the 1D plot.
1124
1125    Examples
1126    --------
1127    Define some Fisher matrices:
1128    >>> m1 = FisherMatrix(
1129    ... [[3, -2], [-2, 5]],
1130    ... names=['a', 'b'],
1131    ... latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'],
1132    ... )
1133    >>> m2 = FisherMatrix(
1134    ... [[4, 1], [1, 6]],
1135    ... names=['a', 'b'],
1136    ... latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'],
1137    ... )
1138
1139    Instantiate a figure:
1140    >>> fig = FisherFigure1D()
1141
1142    Draw marginalized 1D plots with the previously defined Fisher matrix:
1143    >>> fig.plot(m1, label='first')
1144
1145    Add another plot with a different color and style:
1146    >>> fig.plot(m2, label='second', ls=':', color='green')
1147
1148    Draw some other stuff on it:
1149    >>> artist, = fig.draw('a', 'plot', [-1, 0, 1], [-1, 0, 1], color='red', label='curve')
1150    >>> # alternatively, the below will accomplish the same thing
1151    >>> # artist, = fig['a'].plot([-1, 0, 1], [-1, 0, 1], color='red')
1152    >>> # note that in this case, due to certain limitations, you need to
1153    >>> # manually add the legend using a convenience function:
1154    >>> # fig.add_artist_to_legend(artist, label='curve')
1155
1156    Add a legend:
1157    >>> _ = fig.legend(ncol=3, loc='center')
1158
1159    Add a title:
1160    >>> _ = fig.set_title('Example Fisher matrix 1D plotting')
1161
1162    Save it to a file:
1163    >>> fig.savefig(
1164    ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure1d_example1.png",
1165    ... dpi=150)
1166
1167    <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure1d_example1.png">
1168    """
1169
1170    def __init__(
1171        self,
1172        options: Optional[dict] = None,
1173        max_cols: Optional[int] = None,
1174        hspace: float = 0.5,
1175        wspace: float = 0.1,
1176        contour_levels: Optional[Sequence[tuple[float, float]]] = None,
1177    ):
1178        """
1179        Constructor.
1180
1181        Parameters
1182        ----------
1183        options : dict, optional
1184            the dictionary containing the options for plotting. If the special
1185            key 'style' is present, it attempts to use that plotting style (can
1186            be one of the outputs of `matplotlib.pyplot.style.available`, or a
1187            path to a file. If using a file, does not use the default rc
1188            parameters).
1189
1190        max_cols : int, optional
1191            the maximum number of columns in the final plot
1192
1193        hspace : float, optional
1194            The amount of height reserved for space between subplots, expressed
1195            as a fraction of the average axis height.
1196
1197        wspace : float, optional
1198            The amount of width reserved for space between subplots, expressed
1199            as a fraction of the average axis width.
1200
1201        contour_levels : array_like of 2-tuples, optional
1202            the points at which the sigma level should be shaded, along with
1203            the associated opacity (default: None). If not specified, defaults
1204            to `[(1, 0.3), (2, 0.1)]`.
1205
1206        Notes
1207        -----
1208        For the style sheet reference, please consult <a
1209        href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/style_sheets/style_sheets_reference.html"
1210        target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">the matplotlib
1211        documentation</a>.
1212        """
1213        super().__init__(
1214            options=options,
1215            wspace=wspace,
1216            hspace=hspace,
1217            contour_levels=contour_levels,
1218        )
1219        self.max_cols = max_cols
1220        self._ndim = 1
1221        self._hspace = hspace
1222        self._wspace = wspace
1223
1224    def __getitem__(
1225        self,
1226        key: str,
1227    ):
1228        """
1229        Returns the axis associated to the name `key`.
1230        """
1231        if not self.figure:
1232            raise EmptyFigureError
1233
1234        if key not in self.names:
1235            raise ParameterNotFoundError(key, self.names)
1236
1237        return self.axes.flat[np.where(self.names == key)][0]
1238
1239    def draw(
1240        self,
1241        name: str,
1242        method: str,
1243        *args,
1244        **kwargs,
1245    ):
1246        """
1247        Implements drawing of other objects on the axis.
1248
1249        Parameters
1250        ----------
1251        name : str
1252            the name (label) of the parameter where we want to draw
1253
1254        method : str
1255            the name of the method which we want to plot (such as `plot`,
1256            `scatter`, etc.)
1257
1258        *args
1259            any positional arguments passed to the method (usually some data)
1260
1261        **kwargs
1262            any keyword arguments passed to the method (usually styling options)
1263
1264        Returns
1265        -------
1266        Artist
1267            the artist that was drawn on the figure
1268
1269        Raises
1270        ------
1271        EmptyFigureError
1272            if `figure` is not set
1273        """
1274        if not hasattr(self[name], method):
1275            raise AttributeError(
1276                f"The method `{method}` is not a valid plotting method"
1277            )
1278
1279        # get the right color
1280        if "c" not in kwargs and "color" not in kwargs:
1281            kwargs["color"] = next(self.current_color)
1282            self.current_color = iter(self.current_color)
1283
1284        # hopefully the return type should be some artist, or a collection of
1285        # artists
1286        handles = getattr(self[name], method)(*args, **kwargs)
1287        if is_iterable(handles):
1288            for handle in handles:
1289                if isinstance(handle, Artist) and kwargs.get("label"):
1290                    self.labels.append(kwargs.get("label"))
1291                    self.handles.append(handle)
1292        else:
1293            if isinstance(handles, Artist) and kwargs.get("label"):
1294                self.labels.append(kwargs.get("label"))
1295                self.handles.append(handles)
1296
1297        self[name].autoscale()
1298        self[name].relim()
1299        self[name].autoscale_view()
1300
1301        return handles
1302
1303    def plot(
1304        self,
1305        fisher: FisherMatrix,
1306        *args,
1307        mark_fiducials: Union[bool, dict] = False,
1308        **kwargs,
1309    ):
1310        """
1311        Plots the 1D curves of the Fisher objects.
1312
1313        Parameters
1314        ----------
1315        fisher
1316            the Fisher object which we want to plot
1317
1318        mark_fiducials : bool or dict, optional
1319            whether or not the fiducials should be marked on the plots
1320            (default: False). If set to `True`, uses `linestyles='--'` and
1321            `colors='black'` as the default. If a dictionary, accepts the same
1322            keyword arguments as <a
1323            href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/collections_api.html#matplotlib.collections.Collection"
1324            target="_blank" rel="noreferrer
1325            noopener">`matplotlib.collections.Collection`</a>.
1326            If an empty dictionary, uses the default style (determined
1327            automatically).
1328
1329        **kwargs
1330            any keyword arguments used for plotting (same as `plot_curve_1d`)
1331
1332        Returns
1333        -------
1334        None
1335        """
1336        size = len(fisher)
1337
1338        added = False
1339
1340        # in order to preserve colors for each object, we only use the
1341        # (default) cycler when the color is not explicitly set
1342        if "c" not in kwargs and "color" not in kwargs:
1343            kwargs["color"] = next(self.current_color)
1344            self.current_color = iter(self.current_color)
1345
1346        if self.max_cols is not None and self.max_cols <= size:
1347            full = size % self.max_cols == 0
1348            layout = (
1349                size // self.max_cols if full else size // self.max_cols + 1,
1350                self.max_cols,
1351            )
1352        else:
1353            layout = 1, size
1354            full = True
1355
1356        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1357            # general figure setup
1358            if self.figure:
1359                fig = self.figure
1360                axes = self.axes
1361            else:
1362                fig = plt.figure(
1363                    clear=True,
1364                    figsize=(2 * layout[1], 2 * layout[0]),
1365                )
1366                gs = fig.add_gridspec(
1367                    nrows=layout[0],
1368                    ncols=layout[1],
1369                    hspace=self.hspace,
1370                    wspace=self.wspace,
1371                )
1372                axes = gs.subplots()
1373                if size == 1:
1374                    axes = np.array([axes])
1375
1376            for (index, name), latex_name in zip(
1377                enumerate(fisher.names),
1378                fisher.latex_names,
1379            ):
1380                ax = axes.flat[index]
1381
1382                _, __, handle = plot_curve_1d(fisher, name, ax, **kwargs)
1383
1384                if not added and kwargs.get("label"):
1385                    self.handles.append(handle)
1386                    self.labels.append(kwargs["label"])
1387                    added = True
1388
1389                for contour_level in self.contour_levels:
1390                    _add_shading_1d(
1391                        fisher.fiducials[index],
1392                        fisher.constraints(name, marginalized=True),
1393                        ax,
1394                        level=contour_level[0],
1395                        alpha=contour_level[1],
1396                        **kwargs,
1397                    )
1398
1399                ax.autoscale()
1400                ax.set_xlabel(latex_name)
1401                ax.relim()
1402                ax.autoscale_view()
1403
1404                # the y axis should start at 0 since we're plotting a PDF
1405                ax.set_ylim(0, ax.get_ylim()[-1])
1406
1407                ax.set_yticks([])
1408
1409                # marking the fiducials
1410                if not mark_fiducials is False:
1411                    if mark_fiducials is True:
1412                        mark_fiducials = dict(linestyles="--", colors="black")
1413
1414                    _mark_fiducial_1d(
1415                        fisher,
1416                        fisher.names[index],
1417                        ax,
1418                        **mark_fiducials,
1419                    )
1420
1421            # remove any axes which are not drawn
1422            if not full:
1423                for index in range(
1424                    size,
1425                    layout[0] * layout[1],
1426                ):
1427                    # it's simpler to turn off the axis, than completely remove
1428                    # it
1429                    axes.flat[index].axis("off")
1430
1431        self._figure = fig
1432        self._axes = axes
1433        self._names = fisher.names
1434
1435    def legend(
1436        self,
1437        *args: Artist,
1438        overwrite: bool = False,
1439        loc: Union[str, tuple[float, float]] = "lower center",
1440        bbox_to_anchor: Any = (0.5, 1),
1441        **kwargs,
1442    ):
1443        """
1444        Creates a legend on the figure.
1445
1446        Parameters
1447        ----------
1448        *args
1449            any positional arguments for the legend
1450
1451        overwrite : bool, optional
1452            whether to overwrite any "nice" options set by `fitk` (default:
1453            False)
1454
1455        loc : str or tuple of floats, optional
1456            which corner of the legend to use as the positioning anchor
1457            (default: 'lower center')
1458
1459        bbox_to_anchor : Any, optional
1460            the location of where to place the legend (default: `[0.5, 1]`)
1461
1462        **kwargs
1463            any other keyword arguments for the legend
1464
1465        Returns
1466        -------
1467        Artist
1468            the legend that was drawn on the figure
1469
1470        Raises
1471        ------
1472        EmptyFigureError
1473            if `figure` is not set
1474        """
1475        if not self.figure:
1476            raise EmptyFigureError
1477
1478        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1479            ax = self.axes.flat[0]
1480            if not overwrite:
1481                if ax.get_legend():
1482                    ax.get_legend().remove()
1483
1484                return ax.legend(
1485                    self.handles,
1486                    self.labels,
1487                    loc=loc,
1488                    bbox_to_anchor=bbox_to_anchor,
1489                    bbox_transform=self.figure.transFigure,
1490                    **kwargs,
1491                )
1492
1493            return ax.legend(
1494                *args,
1495                loc=loc,
1496                bbox_to_anchor=bbox_to_anchor,
1497                **kwargs,
1498            )

1518
1519        y : float, optional

1522        **kwargs
1523            any keyword arguments to `figure.suptitle`

1525        Returns
1526        -------

1541
1542class FisherFigure2D(_FisherMultipleAxesFigure):
1543    r"""
1544    Container for easy access to elements in the 2D plot.
1545
1546    Examples
1547    --------
1548    Define some Fisher matrices:
1549    >>> m1 = FisherMatrix(
1550    ... [[3, -2], [-2, 5]],
1551    ... names=['a', 'b'],
1552    ... latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'],
1553    ... )
1554    >>> m2 = FisherMatrix(
1555    ... [[4, 1], [1, 6]],
1556    ... names=['a', 'b'],
1557    ... latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'],
1558    ... )
1559
1560    Instantiate a figure:
1561    >>> fig = FisherFigure2D(show_1d_curves=True)
1562
1563    Draw a "triangle plot" with the previously defined Fisher matrix:
1564    >>> fig.plot(m1, label='first')
1565
1566    Add a plot with a different color and style:
1567    >>> fig.plot(m2, label='second', ls=':', color='green')
1568
1569    Draw some other stuff on it:
1570    >>> artist, = fig.draw('a', 'b', 'plot', [-1, 0, 1], [-1, 0, 1], color='red', label='curve')
1571    >>> # alternatively, the below will accomplish the same thing
1572    >>> # artist, = fig['a', 'b'].plot([-1, 0, 1], [-1, 0, 1], color='red')
1573    >>> # note that in this case, due to certain limitations, you need to
1574    >>> # manually add the legend using a convenience function:
1575    >>> # fig.add_artist_to_legend(artist, label='curve')
1576
1577    Add a legend:
1578    >>> _ = fig.legend()
1579
1580    Add a title:
1581    >>> _ = fig.set_title('Example Fisher matrix 2D plotting')
1582
1583    Save it to a file:
1584    >>> fig.savefig(
1585    ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure2d_example1.png",
1586    ... dpi=150)
1587
1588    <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure2d_example1.png">
1589    """
1590
1591    def __init__(
1592        self,
1593        options: Optional[dict] = None,
1594        hspace: float = 0,
1595        wspace: float = 0,
1596        show_1d_curves: bool = False,
1597        show_joint_dist: bool = False,
1598        contour_levels: Optional[Sequence[tuple[float, float]]] = None,
1599    ):
1600        """
1601        Constructor.
1602
1603        Parameters
1604        ----------
1605        options : dict, optional
1606            the dictionary containing the options for plotting. If the special
1607            key 'style' is present, it attempts to use that plotting style (can
1608            be one of the outputs of `matplotlib.pyplot.style.available`, or a
1609            path to a file. If using a file, does not use the default rc
1610            parameters).
1611
1612        hspace : float, optional
1613            The amount of height reserved for space between subplots, expressed
1614            as a fraction of the average axis height.
1615
1616        wspace : float, optional
1617            The amount of width reserved for space between subplots, expressed
1618            as a fraction of the average axis width.
1619
1620        show_1d_curves : bool, optional
1621            whether the 1D marginalized curves should be plotted (default:
1622            False)
1623
1624        show_joint_dist : bool, optional
1625            whether to plot the isocontours of the joint distribution (default:
1626            False)
1627
1628        contour_levels : array_like of 2-tuples, optional
1629            the points at which the sigma level should be shaded, along with
1630            the associated opacity (default: None). If not specified, defaults
1631            to `[(1, 0.3), (2, 0.1)]`.
1632
1633        Notes
1634        -----
1635        For the style sheet reference, please consult <a
1636        href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/style_sheets/style_sheets_reference.html"
1637        target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">the matplotlib
1638        documentation</a>.
1639
1640        **Regarding `show_joint_dist`**: this argument specifies whether we
1641        wish to plot the p-value of the *joint* distribution, or the p-value of
1642        the probability of a single parameter lying within the bounds projected
1643        onto a parameter axis. For more details, see
1644        [arXiv:0906.0664](https://arxiv.org/abs/0906.0664), section 2.
1645        """
1646        super().__init__(
1647            options=options,
1648            wspace=wspace,
1649            hspace=hspace,
1650            contour_levels=contour_levels,
1651        )
1652        self.show_1d_curves = show_1d_curves
1653        self.show_joint_dist = show_joint_dist
1654        self._ndim = 2
1655
1656    def __getitem__(
1657        self,
1658        key: tuple[str, str],
1659    ):
1660        if not self.figure:
1661            raise EmptyFigureError
1662
1663        if not isinstance(key, tuple):
1664            raise TypeError(
1665                f"Incompatible type for element access: expected `tuple`, got `{type(key)}`"
1666            )
1667
1668        name1, name2 = key
1669
1670        if name1 not in self.names:
1671            raise ParameterNotFoundError(name1, self.names)
1672        if name2 not in self.names:
1673            raise ParameterNotFoundError(name2, self.names)
1674
1675        # edge case
1676        if not self.show_1d_curves and name1 == name2:
1677            return None
1678
1679        index1 = np.where(self.names == name1)
1680        index2 = np.where(self.names == name2)
1681
1682        if index1 < index2:
1683            index1, index2 = index2, index1
1684
1685        return self.axes[index1, index2][0, 0]
1686
1687    def legend(
1688        self,
1689        *args: Artist,
1690        overwrite: bool = False,
1691        loc: Union[str, tuple[float, float]] = "upper right",
1692        bbox_to_anchor: Optional[Any] = None,
1693        **kwargs,
1694    ):
1695        """
1696        Creates a legend on the figure.
1697
1698        Parameters
1699        ----------
1700        *args
1701            any positional arguments for the legend
1702
1703        overwrite : bool, optional
1704            whether to overwrite any "nice" options set by `fitk` (default:
1705            False)
1706
1707        loc : str or tuple of floats, optional
1708            which corner of the legend to use as the positioning anchor
1709            (default: 'upper right')
1710
1711        bbox_to_anchor : Any, optional
1712            the location of where to place the legend (default: None, picked by
1713            `fitk` based on information about the plot)
1714
1715        **kwargs
1716            any other keyword arguments for the legend
1717
1718        Returns
1719        -------
1720        Artist
1721            the legend that was drawn on the figure
1722
1723        Raises
1724        ------
1725        EmptyFigureError
1726            if `figure` is not set
1727        """
1728        if not self.figure:
1729            raise EmptyFigureError
1730
1731        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1732            # this will always exist since we can't plot < 2 parameters
1733            ax = self[self.names[0], self.names[1]]
1734            if not overwrite:
1735                if self.show_1d_curves:
1736                    i, j = 0, -1
1737                else:
1738                    i, j = 1, -2
1739
1740                bbox_to_anchor = (
1741                    self.axes[0, j].get_position().xmax,
1742                    self.axes[i, 0].get_position().ymax,
1743                )
1744
1745                if ax.get_legend():
1746                    ax.get_legend().remove()
1747
1748                return ax.legend(
1749                    self.handles,
1750                    self.labels,
1751                    loc=loc,
1752                    bbox_to_anchor=bbox_to_anchor,
1753                    bbox_transform=self.figure.transFigure,
1754                    **kwargs,
1755                )
1756
1757            return ax.legend(
1758                *args,
1759                loc=loc,
1760                bbox_to_anchor=bbox_to_anchor,
1761                **kwargs,
1762            )
1763
1764    def set_title(
1765        self,
1766        *args,
1767        overwrite: bool = False,
1768        xscale: float = 0.5,
1769        yscale: float = 1.08,
1770        **kwargs,
1771    ):
1772        """
1773        Thin wrapper for setting the title of the figure with the correct
1774        options.
1775
1776        Parameters
1777        ----------
1778        *args
1779            any positional arguments to `figure.suptitle`
1780
1781        xscale : float, optional
1782            the x position of the title (default: `0.5`)
1783
1784        yscale : float, optional
1785            the y position of the title (default: `1.08`)
1786
1787        **kwargs
1788            any keyword arguments to `figure.suptitle`
1789
1790        Returns
1791        -------
1792        Artist
1793            the title that was drawn on the figure
1794
1795        Raises
1796        ------
1797        EmptyFigureError
1798            if `figure` is not set
1799        """
1800        if not self.figure:
1801            raise EmptyFigureError
1802
1803        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1804            if not overwrite:
1805                if self.show_1d_curves:
1806                    i, j = 0, -1
1807                else:
1808                    i, j = 1, -2
1809
1810                x, y = (
1811                    self.axes[0, j].get_position().xmax,
1812                    self.axes[i, 0].get_position().ymax,
1813                )
1814
1815                return self.figure.suptitle(
1816                    *args,
1817                    x=x * xscale,
1818                    y=y * yscale,
1819                    **kwargs,
1820                )
1821
1822            return self.figure.suptitle(*args, **kwargs)
1823
1824    def draw(
1825        self,
1826        name1: str,
1827        name2: str,
1828        method: str,
1829        *args,
1830        **kwargs,
1831    ):
1832        """
1833        Implements drawing of other objects on the axis.
1834
1835        Parameters
1836        ----------
1837        name1 : str
1838            the name (label) of the first parameter where we want to draw
1839
1840        name2 : str
1841            the name (label) of the second parameter where we want to draw
1842
1843        method : str
1844            the name of the method which we want to plot (such as `plot`,
1845            `scatter`, etc.)
1846
1847        *args
1848            any positional arguments passed to the method (usually some data)
1849
1850        **kwargs
1851            any keyword arguments passed to the method (usually styling options)
1852
1853        Returns
1854        -------
1855        Artist
1856            the artist that was drawn on the figure
1857
1858        Raises
1859        ------
1860        EmptyFigureError
1861            if `figure` is not set
1862        """
1863        if not hasattr(self[name1, name2], method):
1864            raise AttributeError(
1865                f"The method `{method}` is not a valid plotting method"
1866            )
1867
1868        # get the right color
1869        if "c" not in kwargs and "color" not in kwargs:
1870            kwargs["color"] = next(self.current_color)
1871            self.current_color = iter(self.current_color)
1872
1873        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1874            # hopefully the return type should be some artist, or a collection
1875            # of artists
1876            handles = getattr(self[name1, name2], method)(*args, **kwargs)
1877            if is_iterable(handles):
1878                for handle in handles:
1879                    if isinstance(handle, Artist) and kwargs.get("label"):
1880                        self.labels.append(kwargs["label"])
1881                        self.handles.append(handle)
1882            else:
1883                if isinstance(handles, Artist) and kwargs.get("label"):
1884                    self.labels.append(kwargs["label"])
1885                    self.handles.append(handles)
1886
1887        self[name1, name2].autoscale()
1888        self[name1, name2].relim()
1889        self[name1, name2].autoscale_view()
1890
1891        return handles
1892
1893    def plot(
1894        self,
1895        fisher: FisherMatrix,
1896        *args,
1897        mark_fiducials: Union[bool, dict] = False,
1898        **kwargs,
1899    ):
1900        r"""
1901        Plots the 2D contours (and optionally 1D curves) of the Fisher objects.
1902
1903        Parameters
1904        ----------
1905        fisher : FisherMatrix
1906            the Fisher object which we want to plot
1907
1908        mark_fiducials : bool or dict, optional
1909            whether or not the fiducials should be marked on the plots
1910            (default: False). If set to `True`, uses `linestyles='--'` and
1911            `colors='black'` as the default. If a dictionary, accepts the same
1912            keyword arguments as <a
1913            href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/collections_api.html#matplotlib.collections.Collection"
1914            target="_blank" rel="noreferrer
1915            noopener">`matplotlib.collections.Collection`</a>.
1916            If an empty dictionary, uses the default style (determined
1917            automatically).
1918
1919        **kwargs
1920            any keyword arguments used for plotting (same as `plot_curve_2d`)
1921
1922        Returns
1923        -------
1924        None
1925
1926        Examples
1927        --------
1928        Define a Fisher matrix:
1929        >>> m = FisherMatrix([[3, -2], [-2, 5]], names=['a', 'b'], latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'])
1930
1931        Initiate a figure:
1932        >>> fig = FisherFigure2D(show_1d_curves=True)
1933
1934        Draw a "triangle plot" with the previously defined Fisher matrix:
1935        >>> fig.plot(m)
1936
1937        Save it to a file:
1938        >>> fig.savefig(
1939        ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure2d_plot_example.png",
1940        ... dpi=150)
1941
1942        <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure2d_plot_example.png">
1943        """
1944        size = len(fisher)
1945
1946        if size < 2:
1947            raise ValueError("Unable to make a 2D plot with < 2 parameters")
1948
1949        if self.names is not None:
1950            # make sure they have the same names; if not, raise an error
1951            if set(self.names) != set(fisher.names):
1952                raise ValueError(
1953                    f"The Fisher object names ({fisher.names}) "
1954                    f"do not match those on the figure ({self.names})"
1955                )
1956
1957            # otherwise, we reshuffle them
1958            fisher = fisher.sort(key=self.names)
1959
1960        # in order to preserve colors for each object, we only use the
1961        # (default) cycler when the color is not explicitly set
1962        if "c" not in kwargs and "color" not in kwargs:
1963            kwargs["color"] = next(self.current_color)
1964            self.current_color = iter(self.current_color)
1965
1966        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1967            # general figure setup
1968            if self.figure:
1969                fig = self.figure
1970                ax = self.axes
1971            else:
1972                fig = plt.figure(
1973                    figsize=(2 * size, 2 * size),
1974                    clear=True,
1975                )
1976                ax = fig.add_gridspec(
1977                    nrows=size,
1978                    ncols=size,
1979                    hspace=self.hspace,
1980                    wspace=self.wspace,
1981                ).subplots(
1982                    sharex="col",
1983                    sharey=False,
1984                )
1985
1986            # set automatic limits
1987            for i, j in product(range(size), repeat=2):
1988                if i == j:
1989                    ax[i, i].set_yticks([])
1990                    ax[i, i].set_yticklabels([])
1991                    if i < size - 1:
1992                        ax[i, i].get_xaxis().set_visible(False)
1993                if i > 0 and 0 < j < size - 1:
1994                    ax[i, j].set_yticks([])
1995                    ax[i, j].set_yticklabels([])
1996                if i > j and i != size - 1:
1997                    ax[i, j].get_xaxis().set_visible(False)
1998
1999            # flag for whether the current artist has already been added to the
2000            # legend handle
2001            added = False
2002            # loop over the parameters
2003            for i, j in product(range(len(fisher.names)), repeat=2):
2004                namey, latex_namey, namex, latex_namex = (
2005                    fisher.names[i],
2006                    fisher.latex_names[i],
2007                    fisher.names[j],
2008                    fisher.latex_names[j],
2009                )
2010                # labels for 2D contours (increasing y)
2011                if i > 0 and j == 0:
2012                    ax[i, j].set_ylabel(latex_namey)
2013
2014                # labels for 2D contours (increasing x)
2015                if i == size - 1:
2016                    ax[i, j].set_xlabel(latex_namex)
2017
2018                # removing any unnecessary axes from the gridspec
2019                if i < j and self.figure is None:
2020                    # calling `remove()` is better than `axis("off")` because
2021                    # then we obtain the proper bounding box
2022                    ax[i, j].remove()
2023
2024                # plotting the 2D contours
2025                elif i > j:
2026                    # plot 1-sigma 2D curves
2027                    # NOTE this is the "68% of the probability of a
2028                    # single parameter lying within the bounds projected
2029                    # onto a parameter axis"
2030                    _, __, handle = plot_curve_2d(
2031                        fisher,
2032                        namex,
2033                        namey,
2034                        ax=ax[i, j],
2035                        scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[0][0]
2036                        if not self.show_joint_dist
2037                        else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[0][0])),
2038                        fill=False,
2039                        zorder=20,
2040                        **kwargs,
2041                    )
2042
2043                    if not added and kwargs.get("label"):
2044                        self.handles.append(handle)
2045                        self.labels.append(kwargs["label"])
2046                        added = True
2047
2048                    # same thing, but shaded
2049                    plot_curve_2d(
2050                        fisher,
2051                        namex,
2052                        namey,
2053                        ax=ax[i, j],
2054                        scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[0][0]
2055                        if not self.show_joint_dist
2056                        else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[0][0])),
2057                        fill=True,
2058                        alpha=self.contour_levels[0][1],
2059                        ec=None,
2060                        zorder=20,
2061                        **kwargs,
2062                    )
2063
2064                    for index in range(1, len(self.contour_levels)):
2065                        # the 2-sigma
2066                        plot_curve_2d(
2067                            fisher,
2068                            namex,
2069                            namey,
2070                            ax=ax[i, j],
2071                            scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[index][0]
2072                            if not self.show_joint_dist
2073                            else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[index][0])),
2074                            fill=False,
2075                            zorder=20,
2076                            **kwargs,
2077                        )
2078
2079                        # same thing, but shaded
2080                        plot_curve_2d(
2081                            fisher,
2082                            namex,
2083                            namey,
2084                            ax=ax[i, j],
2085                            scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[index][0]
2086                            if not self.show_joint_dist
2087                            else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[index][0])),
2088                            fill=True,
2089                            alpha=self.contour_levels[index][1],
2090                            ec=None,
2091                            zorder=20,
2092                            **kwargs,
2093                        )
2094
2095                if i == j:
2096                    # plotting the 1D Gaussians
2097                    if self.show_1d_curves is True:
2098                        plot_curve_1d(
2099                            fisher,
2100                            namex,
2101                            ax=ax[i, i],
2102                            **kwargs,
2103                        )
2104
2105                        for contour_level in self.contour_levels:
2106                            _add_shading_1d(
2107                                fisher.fiducials[i],
2108                                fisher.constraints(
2109                                    name=namex,
2110                                    marginalized=True,
2111                                )[0],
2112                                level=contour_level[0],
2113                                ax=ax[i, i],
2114                                alpha=contour_level[1],
2115                                **kwargs,
2116                            )
2117
2118                    else:
2119                        if self.figure is None:
2120                            ax[i, i].remove()
2121
2122            # set automatic limits
2123            for i, j in product(range(size), repeat=2):
2124                try:
2125                    ax[i, j].relim()
2126                    ax[i, j].autoscale_view()
2127                    if i == j:
2128                        ax[i, i].autoscale()
2129                        ax[i, i].set_ylim(0, ax[i, i].get_ylim()[-1])
2130                        ax[i, i].set_yticks([])
2131                        ax[i, i].set_yticklabels([])
2132
2133                        # marking the fiducials (1D)
2134                        if not mark_fiducials is False:
2135                            if mark_fiducials is True:
2136                                mark_fiducials = dict(linestyles="--", colors="black")
2137
2138                            _mark_fiducial_1d(
2139                                fisher,
2140                                fisher.names[i],
2141                                ax[i, i],
2142                                **mark_fiducials,
2143                            )
2144
2145                    else:
2146                        # marking the fiducials (2D)
2147                        if not mark_fiducials is False:
2148                            if mark_fiducials is True:
2149                                mark_fiducials = dict(linestyles="--", colors="black")
2150
2151                            _mark_fiducial_2d(
2152                                fisher,
2153                                fisher.names[i],
2154                                fisher.names[j],
2155                                ax[i, j],
2156                                **mark_fiducials,
2157                            )
2158
2159                except AttributeError:
2160                    pass
2161
2162        self._figure = fig
2163        self._axes = ax
2164        self._names = fisher.names
2165
2166
2167def _get_chisq(
2168    sigma: float = 1,
2169    df: int = 2,
2170):
2171    r"""
2172    Returns $\Delta \chi^2$.
2173    To obtain the scaling coefficient $\alpha$, just take the square root of
2174    the output.
2175
2176    Parameters
2177    ----------
2178    sigma : float = 1
2179        the error on the parameter
2180
2181    df : int = 2
2182        the number of degrees of freedom
2183
2184    Returns
2185    -------
2186    float
2187    """
2188    return chi2.ppf(norm.cdf(sigma) - norm.cdf(-sigma), df=df)
2189
2190
2191def _add_plot_1d(
2192    fiducial: float,
2193    sigma: float,
2194    ax: Optional[Axes] = None,
2195    **kwargs,
2196) -> tuple[Figure, Axes, Artist]:
2197    """
2198    Adds a 1D Gaussian with marginalized constraints `sigma` close to fiducial
2199    value `fiducial` to axis `ax`.
2200    """
2201    if ax is None:
2202        _, ax = plt.subplots()
2203
2204    x = np.linspace(
2205        fiducial - 4 * sigma,
2206        fiducial + 4 * sigma,
2207        100,
2208    )
2209
2210    (handle,) = ax.plot(
2211        x,
2212        [norm.pdf(_, loc=fiducial, scale=sigma) for _ in x],
2213        **kwargs,
2214    )
2215
2216    return (ax.get_figure(), ax, handle)
2217
2218
2219def _add_shading_1d(
2220    fiducial: float,
2221    sigma: float,
2222    ax: Optional[Axes] = None,
2223    level: float = 1,
2224    **kwargs,
2225) -> tuple[Figure, Axes]:
2226    """
2227    Add shading to a 1D axes.
2228    """
2229    if ax is None:
2230        _, ax = plt.subplots()
2231
2232    # keyword args which have no effect on the plotting
2233    unused_kwargs = [
2234        "lw",
2235        "linewidth",
2236        "ec",
2237        "edgecolor",
2238        "fc",
2239        "facecolor",
2240    ]
2241    for kwarg in unused_kwargs:
2242        kwargs.pop(kwarg, None)
2243
2244    # the kwarg `color` supersedes `facecolor`, hence we need to remove it from
2245    # the passed kwargs, and call `fill_between` with `facecolor=color`
2246    color = kwargs.pop("color", None)
2247
2248    x = np.ndarray.flatten(
2249        np.linspace(
2250            fiducial - level * sigma,
2251            fiducial + level * sigma,
2252            100,
2253        )
2254    )
2255
2256    ax.fill_between(
2257        x,
2258        np.ndarray.flatten(
2259            np.array([norm.pdf(_, loc=fiducial, scale=sigma) for _ in x])
2260        ),
2261        edgecolor=None,
2262        facecolor=color,
2263        **kwargs,
2264    )
2265
2266    return (ax.get_figure(), ax)
