class FisherFigure2D(_FisherMultipleAxesFigure): 
1543class FisherFigure2D(_FisherMultipleAxesFigure):
1544    r"""
1545    Container for easy access to elements in the 2D plot.
1546
1547    Examples
1548    --------
1549    Define some Fisher matrices:
1550    >>> m1 = FisherMatrix(
1551    ... [[3, -2], [-2, 5]],
1552    ... names=['a', 'b'],
1553    ... latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'],
1554    ... )
1555    >>> m2 = FisherMatrix(
1556    ... [[4, 1], [1, 6]],
1557    ... names=['a', 'b'],
1558    ... latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'],
1559    ... )
1560
1561    Instantiate a figure:
1562    >>> fig = FisherFigure2D(show_1d_curves=True)
1563
1564    Draw a "triangle plot" with the previously defined Fisher matrix:
1565    >>> fig.plot(m1, label='first')
1566
1567    Add a plot with a different color and style:
1568    >>> fig.plot(m2, label='second', ls=':', color='green')
1569
1570    Draw some other stuff on it:
1571    >>> artist, = fig.draw('a', 'b', 'plot', [-1, 0, 1], [-1, 0, 1], color='red', label='curve')
1572    >>> # alternatively, the below will accomplish the same thing
1573    >>> # artist, = fig['a', 'b'].plot([-1, 0, 1], [-1, 0, 1], color='red')
1574    >>> # note that in this case, due to certain limitations, you need to
1575    >>> # manually add the legend using a convenience function:
1576    >>> # fig.add_artist_to_legend(artist, label='curve')
1577
1578    Add a legend:
1579    >>> _ = fig.legend()
1580
1581    Add a title:
1582    >>> _ = fig.set_title('Example Fisher matrix 2D plotting')
1583
1584    Save it to a file:
1585    >>> fig.savefig(
1586    ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure2d_example1.png",
1587    ... dpi=150)
1588
1589    <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure2d_example1.png">
1590    """
1591
1592    def __init__(
1593        self,
1594        options: Optional[dict] = None,
1595        hspace: float = 0,
1596        wspace: float = 0,
1597        show_1d_curves: bool = False,
1598        show_joint_dist: bool = False,
1599        contour_levels: Optional[Sequence[tuple[float, float]]] = None,
1600    ):
1601        """
1602        Constructor.
1603
1604        Parameters
1605        ----------
1606        options : dict, optional
1607            the dictionary containing the options for plotting. If the special
1608            key 'style' is present, it attempts to use that plotting style (can
1609            be one of the outputs of `matplotlib.pyplot.style.available`, or a
1610            path to a file. If using a file, does not use the default rc
1611            parameters).
1612
1613        hspace : float, optional
1614            The amount of height reserved for space between subplots, expressed
1615            as a fraction of the average axis height.
1616
1617        wspace : float, optional
1618            The amount of width reserved for space between subplots, expressed
1619            as a fraction of the average axis width.
1620
1621        show_1d_curves : bool, optional
1622            whether the 1D marginalized curves should be plotted (default:
1623            False)
1624
1625        show_joint_dist : bool, optional
1626            whether to plot the isocontours of the joint distribution (default:
1627            False)
1628
1629        contour_levels : array_like of 2-tuples, optional
1630            the points at which the sigma level should be shaded, along with
1631            the associated opacity (default: None). If not specified, defaults
1632            to `[(1, 0.3), (2, 0.1)]`.
1633
1634        Notes
1635        -----
1636        For the style sheet reference, please consult <a
1637        href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/style_sheets/style_sheets_reference.html"
1638        target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">the matplotlib
1639        documentation</a>.
1640
1641        **Regarding `show_joint_dist`**: this argument specifies whether we
1642        wish to plot the p-value of the *joint* distribution, or the p-value of
1643        the probability of a single parameter lying within the bounds projected
1644        onto a parameter axis. For more details, see
1645        [arXiv:0906.0664](https://arxiv.org/abs/0906.0664), section 2.
1646        """
1647        super().__init__(
1648            options=options,
1649            wspace=wspace,
1650            hspace=hspace,
1651            contour_levels=contour_levels,
1652        )
1653        self.show_1d_curves = show_1d_curves
1654        self.show_joint_dist = show_joint_dist
1655        self._ndim = 2
1656
1657    def __getitem__(
1658        self,
1659        key: tuple[str, str],
1660    ):
1661        if not self.figure:
1662            raise EmptyFigureError
1663
1664        if not isinstance(key, tuple):
1665            raise TypeError(
1666                f"Incompatible type for element access: expected `tuple`, got `{type(key)}`"
1667            )
1668
1669        name1, name2 = key
1670
1671        if name1 not in self.names:
1672            raise ParameterNotFoundError(name1, self.names)
1673        if name2 not in self.names:
1674            raise ParameterNotFoundError(name2, self.names)
1675
1676        # edge case
1677        if not self.show_1d_curves and name1 == name2:
1678            return None
1679
1680        index1 = np.where(self.names == name1)
1681        index2 = np.where(self.names == name2)
1682
1683        if index1 < index2:
1684            index1, index2 = index2, index1
1685
1686        return self.axes[index1, index2][0, 0]
1687
1688    def legend(
1689        self,
1690        *args: Artist,
1691        overwrite: bool = False,
1692        loc: Union[str, tuple[float, float]] = "upper right",
1693        bbox_to_anchor: Optional[Any] = None,
1694        **kwargs,
1695    ):
1696        """
1697        Creates a legend on the figure.
1698
1699        Parameters
1700        ----------
1701        *args
1702            any positional arguments for the legend
1703
1704        overwrite : bool, optional
1705            whether to overwrite any "nice" options set by `fitk` (default:
1706            False)
1707
1708        loc : str or tuple of floats, optional
1709            which corner of the legend to use as the positioning anchor
1710            (default: 'upper right')
1711
1712        bbox_to_anchor : Any, optional
1713            the location of where to place the legend (default: None, picked by
1714            `fitk` based on information about the plot)
1715
1716        **kwargs
1717            any other keyword arguments for the legend
1718
1719        Returns
1720        -------
1721        Artist
1722            the legend that was drawn on the figure
1723
1724        Raises
1725        ------
1726        EmptyFigureError
1727            if `figure` is not set
1728        """
1729        if not self.figure:
1730            raise EmptyFigureError
1731
1732        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1733            # this will always exist since we can't plot < 2 parameters
1734            ax = self[self.names[0], self.names[1]]
1735            if not overwrite:
1736                if self.show_1d_curves:
1737                    i, j = 0, -1
1738                else:
1739                    i, j = 1, -2
1740
1741                bbox_to_anchor = (
1742                    self.axes[0, j].get_position().xmax,
1743                    self.axes[i, 0].get_position().ymax,
1744                )
1745
1746                if ax.get_legend():
1747                    ax.get_legend().remove()
1748
1749                return ax.legend(
1750                    self.handles,
1751                    self.labels,
1752                    loc=loc,
1753                    bbox_to_anchor=bbox_to_anchor,
1754                    bbox_transform=self.figure.transFigure,
1755                    **kwargs,
1756                )
1757
1758            return ax.legend(
1759                *args,
1760                loc=loc,
1761                bbox_to_anchor=bbox_to_anchor,
1762                **kwargs,
1763            )
1764
1765    def set_title(
1766        self,
1767        *args,
1768        overwrite: bool = False,
1769        xscale: float = 0.5,
1770        yscale: float = 1.08,
1771        **kwargs,
1772    ):
1773        """
1774        Thin wrapper for setting the title of the figure with the correct
1775        options.
1776
1777        Parameters
1778        ----------
1779        *args
1780            any positional arguments to `figure.suptitle`
1781
1782        xscale : float, optional
1783            the x position of the title (default: `0.5`)
1784
1785        yscale : float, optional
1786            the y position of the title (default: `1.08`)
1787
1788        **kwargs
1789            any keyword arguments to `figure.suptitle`
1790
1791        Returns
1792        -------
1793        Artist
1794            the title that was drawn on the figure
1795
1796        Raises
1797        ------
1798        EmptyFigureError
1799            if `figure` is not set
1800        """
1801        if not self.figure:
1802            raise EmptyFigureError
1803
1804        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1805            if not overwrite:
1806                if self.show_1d_curves:
1807                    i, j = 0, -1
1808                else:
1809                    i, j = 1, -2
1810
1811                x, y = (
1812                    self.axes[0, j].get_position().xmax,
1813                    self.axes[i, 0].get_position().ymax,
1814                )
1815
1816                return self.figure.suptitle(
1817                    *args,
1818                    x=x * xscale,
1819                    y=y * yscale,
1820                    **kwargs,
1821                )
1822
1823            return self.figure.suptitle(*args, **kwargs)
1824
1825    def draw(
1826        self,
1827        name1: str,
1828        name2: str,
1829        method: str,
1830        *args,
1831        **kwargs,
1832    ):
1833        """
1834        Implements drawing of other objects on the axis.
1835
1836        Parameters
1837        ----------
1838        name1 : str
1839            the name (label) of the first parameter where we want to draw
1840
1841        name2 : str
1842            the name (label) of the second parameter where we want to draw
1843
1844        method : str
1845            the name of the method which we want to plot (such as `plot`,
1846            `scatter`, etc.)
1847
1848        *args
1849            any positional arguments passed to the method (usually some data)
1850
1851        **kwargs
1852            any keyword arguments passed to the method (usually styling options)
1853
1854        Returns
1855        -------
1856        Artist
1857            the artist that was drawn on the figure
1858
1859        Raises
1860        ------
1861        EmptyFigureError
1862            if `figure` is not set
1863        """
1864        if not hasattr(self[name1, name2], method):
1865            raise AttributeError(
1866                f"The method `{method}` is not a valid plotting method"
1867            )
1868
1869        # get the right color
1870        if "c" not in kwargs and "color" not in kwargs:
1871            kwargs["color"] = next(self.current_color)
1872            self.current_color = iter(self.current_color)
1873
1874        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1875            # hopefully the return type should be some artist, or a collection
1876            # of artists
1877            handles = getattr(self[name1, name2], method)(*args, **kwargs)
1878            if is_iterable(handles):
1879                for handle in handles:
1880                    if isinstance(handle, Artist) and kwargs.get("label"):
1881                        self.labels.append(kwargs["label"])
1882                        self.handles.append(handle)
1883            else:
1884                if isinstance(handles, Artist) and kwargs.get("label"):
1885                    self.labels.append(kwargs["label"])
1886                    self.handles.append(handles)
1887
1888        self[name1, name2].autoscale()
1889        self[name1, name2].relim()
1890        self[name1, name2].autoscale_view()
1891
1892        return handles
1893
1894    def plot(
1895        self,
1896        fisher: FisherMatrix,
1897        *args,
1898        mark_fiducials: Union[bool, dict] = False,
1899        **kwargs,
1900    ):
1901        r"""
1902        Plots the 2D contours (and optionally 1D curves) of the Fisher objects.
1903
1904        Parameters
1905        ----------
1906        fisher : FisherMatrix
1907            the Fisher object which we want to plot
1908
1909        mark_fiducials : bool or dict, optional
1910            whether or not the fiducials should be marked on the plots
1911            (default: False). If set to `True`, uses `linestyles='--'` and
1912            `colors='black'` as the default. If a dictionary, accepts the same
1913            keyword arguments as <a
1914            href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/collections_api.html#matplotlib.collections.Collection"
1915            target="_blank" rel="noreferrer
1916            noopener">`matplotlib.collections.Collection`</a>.
1917            If an empty dictionary, uses the default style (determined
1918            automatically).
1919
1920        **kwargs
1921            any keyword arguments used for plotting (same as `plot_curve_2d`)
1922
1923        Returns
1924        -------
1925        None
1926
1927        Examples
1928        --------
1929        Define a Fisher matrix:
1930        >>> m = FisherMatrix([[3, -2], [-2, 5]], names=['a', 'b'], latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'])
1931
1932        Initiate a figure:
1933        >>> fig = FisherFigure2D(show_1d_curves=True)
1934
1935        Draw a "triangle plot" with the previously defined Fisher matrix:
1936        >>> fig.plot(m)
1937
1938        Save it to a file:
1939        >>> fig.savefig(
1940        ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure2d_plot_example.png",
1941        ... dpi=150)
1942
1943        <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure2d_plot_example.png">
1944        """
1945        size = len(fisher)
1946
1947        if size < 2:
1948            raise ValueError("Unable to make a 2D plot with < 2 parameters")
1949
1950        if self.names is not None:
1951            # make sure they have the same names; if not, raise an error
1952            if set(self.names) != set(fisher.names):
1953                raise ValueError(
1954                    f"The Fisher object names ({fisher.names}) "
1955                    f"do not match those on the figure ({self.names})"
1956                )
1957
1958            # otherwise, we reshuffle them
1959            fisher = fisher.sort(key=self.names)
1960
1961        # in order to preserve colors for each object, we only use the
1962        # (default) cycler when the color is not explicitly set
1963        if "c" not in kwargs and "color" not in kwargs:
1964            kwargs["color"] = next(self.current_color)
1965            self.current_color = iter(self.current_color)
1966
1967        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1968            # general figure setup
1969            if self.figure:
1970                fig = self.figure
1971                ax = self.axes
1972            else:
1973                fig = plt.figure(
1974                    figsize=(2 * size, 2 * size),
1975                    clear=True,
1976                )
1977                ax = fig.add_gridspec(
1978                    nrows=size,
1979                    ncols=size,
1980                    hspace=self.hspace,
1981                    wspace=self.wspace,
1982                ).subplots(
1983                    sharex="col",
1984                    sharey=False,
1985                )
1986
1987            # set automatic limits
1988            for i, j in product(range(size), repeat=2):
1989                if i == j:
1990                    ax[i, i].set_yticks([])
1991                    ax[i, i].set_yticklabels([])
1992                    if i < size - 1:
1993                        ax[i, i].get_xaxis().set_visible(False)
1994                if i > 0 and 0 < j < size - 1:
1995                    ax[i, j].set_yticks([])
1996                    ax[i, j].set_yticklabels([])
1997                if i > j and i != size - 1:
1998                    ax[i, j].get_xaxis().set_visible(False)
1999
2000            # flag for whether the current artist has already been added to the
2001            # legend handle
2002            added = False
2003            # loop over the parameters
2004            for i, j in product(range(len(fisher.names)), repeat=2):
2005                namey, latex_namey, namex, latex_namex = (
2006                    fisher.names[i],
2007                    fisher.latex_names[i],
2008                    fisher.names[j],
2009                    fisher.latex_names[j],
2010                )
2011                # labels for 2D contours (increasing y)
2012                if i > 0 and j == 0:
2013                    ax[i, j].set_ylabel(latex_namey)
2014
2015                # labels for 2D contours (increasing x)
2016                if i == size - 1:
2017                    ax[i, j].set_xlabel(latex_namex)
2018
2019                # removing any unnecessary axes from the gridspec
2020                if i < j and self.figure is None:
2021                    # calling `remove()` is better than `axis("off")` because
2022                    # then we obtain the proper bounding box
2023                    ax[i, j].remove()
2024
2025                # plotting the 2D contours
2026                elif i > j:
2027                    # plot 1-sigma 2D curves
2028                    # NOTE this is the "68% of the probability of a
2029                    # single parameter lying within the bounds projected
2030                    # onto a parameter axis"
2031                    _, __, handle = plot_curve_2d(
2032                        fisher,
2033                        namex,
2034                        namey,
2035                        ax=ax[i, j],
2036                        scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[0][0]
2037                        if not self.show_joint_dist
2038                        else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[0][0])),
2039                        fill=False,
2040                        zorder=20,
2041                        **kwargs,
2042                    )
2043
2044                    if not added and kwargs.get("label"):
2045                        self.handles.append(handle)
2046                        self.labels.append(kwargs["label"])
2047                        added = True
2048
2049                    # same thing, but shaded
2050                    plot_curve_2d(
2051                        fisher,
2052                        namex,
2053                        namey,
2054                        ax=ax[i, j],
2055                        scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[0][0]
2056                        if not self.show_joint_dist
2057                        else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[0][0])),
2058                        fill=True,
2059                        alpha=self.contour_levels[0][1],
2060                        ec=None,
2061                        zorder=20,
2062                        **kwargs,
2063                    )
2064
2065                    for index in range(1, len(self.contour_levels)):
2066                        # the 2-sigma
2067                        plot_curve_2d(
2068                            fisher,
2069                            namex,
2070                            namey,
2071                            ax=ax[i, j],
2072                            scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[index][0]
2073                            if not self.show_joint_dist
2074                            else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[index][0])),
2075                            fill=False,
2076                            zorder=20,
2077                            **kwargs,
2078                        )
2079
2080                        # same thing, but shaded
2081                        plot_curve_2d(
2082                            fisher,
2083                            namex,
2084                            namey,
2085                            ax=ax[i, j],
2086                            scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[index][0]
2087                            if not self.show_joint_dist
2088                            else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[index][0])),
2089                            fill=True,
2090                            alpha=self.contour_levels[index][1],
2091                            ec=None,
2092                            zorder=20,
2093                            **kwargs,
2094                        )
2095
2096                if i == j:
2097                    # plotting the 1D Gaussians
2098                    if self.show_1d_curves is True:
2099                        plot_curve_1d(
2100                            fisher,
2101                            namex,
2102                            ax=ax[i, i],
2103                            **kwargs,
2104                        )
2105
2106                        for contour_level in self.contour_levels:
2107                            _add_shading_1d(
2108                                fisher.fiducials[i],
2109                                fisher.constraints(
2110                                    name=namex,
2111                                    marginalized=True,
2112                                )[0],
2113                                level=contour_level[0],
2114                                ax=ax[i, i],
2115                                alpha=contour_level[1],
2116                                **kwargs,
2117                            )
2118
2119                    else:
2120                        if self.figure is None:
2121                            ax[i, i].remove()
2122
2123            # set automatic limits
2124            for i, j in product(range(size), repeat=2):
2125                try:
2126                    ax[i, j].relim()
2127                    ax[i, j].autoscale_view()
2128                    if i == j:
2129                        ax[i, i].autoscale()
2130                        ax[i, i].set_ylim(0, ax[i, i].get_ylim()[-1])
2131                        ax[i, i].set_yticks([])
2132                        ax[i, i].set_yticklabels([])
2133
2134                        # marking the fiducials (1D)
2135                        if not mark_fiducials is False:
2136                            if mark_fiducials is True:
2137                                mark_fiducials = dict(linestyles="--", colors="black")
2138
2139                            _mark_fiducial_1d(
2140                                fisher,
2141                                fisher.names[i],
2142                                ax[i, i],
2143                                **mark_fiducials,
2144                            )
2145
2146                    else:
2147                        # marking the fiducials (2D)
2148                        if not mark_fiducials is False:
2149                            if mark_fiducials is True:
2150                                mark_fiducials = dict(linestyles="--", colors="black")
2151
2152                            _mark_fiducial_2d(
2153                                fisher,
2154                                fisher.names[i],
2155                                fisher.names[j],
2156                                ax[i, j],
2157                                **mark_fiducials,
2158                            )
2159
2160                except AttributeError:
2161                    pass
2162
2163        self._figure = fig
2164        self._axes = ax
2165        self._names = fisher.names

Container for easy access to elements in the 2D plot.

Examples

Define some Fisher matrices:

>>> m1 = FisherMatrix(
... [[3, -2], [-2, 5]],
... names=['a', 'b'],
... latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'],
... )
>>> m2 = FisherMatrix(
... [[4, 1], [1, 6]],
... names=['a', 'b'],
... latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'],
... )

Instantiate a figure:

>>> fig = FisherFigure2D(show_1d_curves=True)

Draw a "triangle plot" with the previously defined Fisher matrix:

>>> fig.plot(m1, label='first')

Add a plot with a different color and style:

>>> fig.plot(m2, label='second', ls=':', color='green')

Draw some other stuff on it:

>>> artist, = fig.draw('a', 'b', 'plot', [-1, 0, 1], [-1, 0, 1], color='red', label='curve')
>>> # alternatively, the below will accomplish the same thing
>>> # artist, = fig['a', 'b'].plot([-1, 0, 1], [-1, 0, 1], color='red')
>>> # note that in this case, due to certain limitations, you need to
>>> # manually add the legend using a convenience function:
>>> # fig.add_artist_to_legend(artist, label='curve')

Add a legend:

>>> _ = fig.legend()

Add a title:

>>> _ = fig.set_title('Example Fisher matrix 2D plotting')

Save it to a file:

>>> fig.savefig(
... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure2d_example1.png",
... dpi=150)

Constructor.

Parameters
  • options (dict, optional): the dictionary containing the options for plotting. If the special key 'style' is present, it attempts to use that plotting style (can be one of the outputs of matplotlib.pyplot.style.available, or a path to a file. If using a file, does not use the default rc parameters).
  • hspace (float, optional): The amount of height reserved for space between subplots, expressed as a fraction of the average axis height.
  • wspace (float, optional): The amount of width reserved for space between subplots, expressed as a fraction of the average axis width.
  • show_1d_curves (bool, optional): whether the 1D marginalized curves should be plotted (default: False)
  • show_joint_dist (bool, optional): whether to plot the isocontours of the joint distribution (default: False)
  • contour_levels (array_like of 2-tuples, optional): the points at which the sigma level should be shaded, along with the associated opacity (default: None). If not specified, defaults to [(1, 0.3), (2, 0.1)].
Notes

For the style sheet reference, please consult the matplotlib documentation.

Regarding show_joint_dist: this argument specifies whether we wish to plot the p-value of the joint distribution, or the p-value of the probability of a single parameter lying within the bounds projected onto a parameter axis. For more details, see arXiv:0906.0664, section 2.

def plot( self, fisher: fitk.tensors.FisherMatrix, *args, mark_fiducials: Union[bool, dict] = False, **kwargs): 
1894    def plot(
1895        self,
1896        fisher: FisherMatrix,
1897        *args,
1898        mark_fiducials: Union[bool, dict] = False,
1899        **kwargs,
1900    ):
1901        r"""
1902        Plots the 2D contours (and optionally 1D curves) of the Fisher objects.
1903
1904        Parameters
1905        ----------
1906        fisher : FisherMatrix
1907            the Fisher object which we want to plot
1908
1909        mark_fiducials : bool or dict, optional
1910            whether or not the fiducials should be marked on the plots
1911            (default: False). If set to `True`, uses `linestyles='--'` and
1912            `colors='black'` as the default. If a dictionary, accepts the same
1913            keyword arguments as <a
1914            href="https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/collections_api.html#matplotlib.collections.Collection"
1915            target="_blank" rel="noreferrer
1916            noopener">`matplotlib.collections.Collection`</a>.
1917            If an empty dictionary, uses the default style (determined
1918            automatically).
1919
1920        **kwargs
1921            any keyword arguments used for plotting (same as `plot_curve_2d`)
1922
1923        Returns
1924        -------
1925        None
1926
1927        Examples
1928        --------
1929        Define a Fisher matrix:
1930        >>> m = FisherMatrix([[3, -2], [-2, 5]], names=['a', 'b'], latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'])
1931
1932        Initiate a figure:
1933        >>> fig = FisherFigure2D(show_1d_curves=True)
1934
1935        Draw a "triangle plot" with the previously defined Fisher matrix:
1936        >>> fig.plot(m)
1937
1938        Save it to a file:
1939        >>> fig.savefig(
1940        ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure2d_plot_example.png",
1941        ... dpi=150)
1942
1943        <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/fisher_figure2d_plot_example.png">
1944        """
1945        size = len(fisher)
1946
1947        if size < 2:
1948            raise ValueError("Unable to make a 2D plot with < 2 parameters")
1949
1950        if self.names is not None:
1951            # make sure they have the same names; if not, raise an error
1952            if set(self.names) != set(fisher.names):
1953                raise ValueError(
1954                    f"The Fisher object names ({fisher.names}) "
1955                    f"do not match those on the figure ({self.names})"
1956                )
1957
1958            # otherwise, we reshuffle them
1959            fisher = fisher.sort(key=self.names)
1960
1961        # in order to preserve colors for each object, we only use the
1962        # (default) cycler when the color is not explicitly set
1963        if "c" not in kwargs and "color" not in kwargs:
1964            kwargs["color"] = next(self.current_color)
1965            self.current_color = iter(self.current_color)
1966
1967        with plt.rc_context(self.options):
1968            # general figure setup
1969            if self.figure:
1970                fig = self.figure
1971                ax = self.axes
1972            else:
1973                fig = plt.figure(
1974                    figsize=(2 * size, 2 * size),
1975                    clear=True,
1976                )
1977                ax = fig.add_gridspec(
1978                    nrows=size,
1979                    ncols=size,
1980                    hspace=self.hspace,
1981                    wspace=self.wspace,
1982                ).subplots(
1983                    sharex="col",
1984                    sharey=False,
1985                )
1986
1987            # set automatic limits
1988            for i, j in product(range(size), repeat=2):
1989                if i == j:
1990                    ax[i, i].set_yticks([])
1991                    ax[i, i].set_yticklabels([])
1992                    if i < size - 1:
1993                        ax[i, i].get_xaxis().set_visible(False)
1994                if i > 0 and 0 < j < size - 1:
1995                    ax[i, j].set_yticks([])
1996                    ax[i, j].set_yticklabels([])
1997                if i > j and i != size - 1:
1998                    ax[i, j].get_xaxis().set_visible(False)
1999
2000            # flag for whether the current artist has already been added to the
2001            # legend handle
2002            added = False
2003            # loop over the parameters
2004            for i, j in product(range(len(fisher.names)), repeat=2):
2005                namey, latex_namey, namex, latex_namex = (
2006                    fisher.names[i],
2007                    fisher.latex_names[i],
2008                    fisher.names[j],
2009                    fisher.latex_names[j],
2010                )
2011                # labels for 2D contours (increasing y)
2012                if i > 0 and j == 0:
2013                    ax[i, j].set_ylabel(latex_namey)
2014
2015                # labels for 2D contours (increasing x)
2016                if i == size - 1:
2017                    ax[i, j].set_xlabel(latex_namex)
2018
2019                # removing any unnecessary axes from the gridspec
2020                if i < j and self.figure is None:
2021                    # calling `remove()` is better than `axis("off")` because
2022                    # then we obtain the proper bounding box
2023                    ax[i, j].remove()
2024
2025                # plotting the 2D contours
2026                elif i > j:
2027                    # plot 1-sigma 2D curves
2028                    # NOTE this is the "68% of the probability of a
2029                    # single parameter lying within the bounds projected
2030                    # onto a parameter axis"
2031                    _, __, handle = plot_curve_2d(
2032                        fisher,
2033                        namex,
2034                        namey,
2035                        ax=ax[i, j],
2036                        scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[0][0]
2037                        if not self.show_joint_dist
2038                        else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[0][0])),
2039                        fill=False,
2040                        zorder=20,
2041                        **kwargs,
2042                    )
2043
2044                    if not added and kwargs.get("label"):
2045                        self.handles.append(handle)
2046                        self.labels.append(kwargs["label"])
2047                        added = True
2048
2049                    # same thing, but shaded
2050                    plot_curve_2d(
2051                        fisher,
2052                        namex,
2053                        namey,
2054                        ax=ax[i, j],
2055                        scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[0][0]
2056                        if not self.show_joint_dist
2057                        else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[0][0])),
2058                        fill=True,
2059                        alpha=self.contour_levels[0][1],
2060                        ec=None,
2061                        zorder=20,
2062                        **kwargs,
2063                    )
2064
2065                    for index in range(1, len(self.contour_levels)):
2066                        # the 2-sigma
2067                        plot_curve_2d(
2068                            fisher,
2069                            namex,
2070                            namey,
2071                            ax=ax[i, j],
2072                            scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[index][0]
2073                            if not self.show_joint_dist
2074                            else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[index][0])),
2075                            fill=False,
2076                            zorder=20,
2077                            **kwargs,
2078                        )
2079
2080                        # same thing, but shaded
2081                        plot_curve_2d(
2082                            fisher,
2083                            namex,
2084                            namey,
2085                            ax=ax[i, j],
2086                            scaling_factor=self.contour_levels[index][0]
2087                            if not self.show_joint_dist
2088                            else np.sqrt(_get_chisq(self.contour_levels[index][0])),
2089                            fill=True,
2090                            alpha=self.contour_levels[index][1],
2091                            ec=None,
2092                            zorder=20,
2093                            **kwargs,
2094                        )
2095
2096                if i == j:
2097                    # plotting the 1D Gaussians
2098                    if self.show_1d_curves is True:
2099                        plot_curve_1d(
2100                            fisher,
2101                            namex,
2102                            ax=ax[i, i],
2103                            **kwargs,
2104                        )
2105
2106                        for contour_level in self.contour_levels:
2107                            _add_shading_1d(
2108                                fisher.fiducials[i],
2109                                fisher.constraints(
2110                                    name=namex,
2111                                    marginalized=True,
2112                                )[0],
2113                                level=contour_level[0],
2114                                ax=ax[i, i],
2115                                alpha=contour_level[1],
2116                                **kwargs,
2117                            )
2118
2119                    else:
2120                        if self.figure is None:
2121                            ax[i, i].remove()
2122
2123            # set automatic limits
2124            for i, j in product(range(size), repeat=2):
2125                try:
2126                    ax[i, j].relim()
2127                    ax[i, j].autoscale_view()
2128                    if i == j:
2129                        ax[i, i].autoscale()
2130                        ax[i, i].set_ylim(0, ax[i, i].get_ylim()[-1])
2131                        ax[i, i].set_yticks([])
2132                        ax[i, i].set_yticklabels([])
2133
2134                        # marking the fiducials (1D)
2135                        if not mark_fiducials is False:
2136                            if mark_fiducials is True:
2137                                mark_fiducials = dict(linestyles="--", colors="black")
2138
2139                            _mark_fiducial_1d(
2140                                fisher,
2141                                fisher.names[i],
2142                                ax[i, i],
2143                                **mark_fiducials,
2144                            )
2145
2146                    else:
2147                        # marking the fiducials (2D)
2148                        if not mark_fiducials is False:
2149                            if mark_fiducials is True:
2150                                mark_fiducials = dict(linestyles="--", colors="black")
2151
2152                            _mark_fiducial_2d(
2153                                fisher,
2154                                fisher.names[i],
2155                                fisher.names[j],
2156                                ax[i, j],
2157                                **mark_fiducials,
2158                            )
2159
2160                except AttributeError:
2161                    pass
2162
2163        self._figure = fig
2164        self._axes = ax
2165        self._names = fisher.names

Plots the 2D contours (and optionally 1D curves) of the Fisher objects.

Parameters
  • fisher (FisherMatrix): the Fisher object which we want to plot
  • mark_fiducials (bool or dict, optional): whether or not the fiducials should be marked on the plots (default: False). If set to True, uses linestyles='--' and colors='black' as the default. If a dictionary, accepts the same keyword arguments as matplotlib.collections.Collection. If an empty dictionary, uses the default style (determined automatically).
  • **kwargs: any keyword arguments used for plotting (same as plot_curve_2d)
Returns
  • None
Examples

Define a Fisher matrix:

>>> m = FisherMatrix([[3, -2], [-2, 5]], names=['a', 'b'], latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'])

Initiate a figure:

>>> fig = FisherFigure2D(show_1d_curves=True)

Draw a "triangle plot" with the previously defined Fisher matrix:

>>> fig.plot(m)

Save it to a file:

>>> fig.savefig(
... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "fisher_figure2d_plot_example.png",
... dpi=150)

hspace: float

The amount of height reserved for space between subplots, expressed as a fraction of the average axis height.

wspace: float

The amount of width reserved for space between subplots, expressed as a fraction of the average axis width.

names

Returns the names of the original parameters plotted.

425    def set_tick_params(
426        self,
427        which: str = "both",
428        **kwargs,
429    ):
430        """
431        Collectively sets both x and y tick parameters.
432
433        Parameters
434        ----------
435        which : {'both', 'x', 'y'}
436            which axis to change (default: 'both')
437
438        **kwargs
439            any keyword arguments passed to the methods for handling tick
440            parameters (such as 'fontsize', 'rotation', etc.)
441
442        Returns
443        -------
444        None
445
446        Raises
447        ------
448        EmptyFigureError
449            if `figure` is not set
450        """
451        if not self.figure:
452            raise EmptyFigureError
453
454        for nameiter in product(self.names, repeat=self._ndim):
455            if self[nameiter] and which in ["both", "x"]:
456                for item in self[nameiter].get_xticklabels():
457                    for key, value in kwargs.items():
458                        getattr(item, f"set_{key}")(value)
459            if self[nameiter] and which in ["both", "y"]:
460                for item in self[nameiter].get_yticklabels():
461                    for key, value in kwargs.items():
462                        getattr(item, f"set_{key}")(value)
463            # also alter any exponential offsets
464            for key, value in kwargs.items():
465                if self[nameiter] and which in ["both", "x"]:
466                    getattr(
467                        self[nameiter].get_xaxis().get_offset_text(),
468                        f"set_{key}",
469                    )(value)
470                if self[nameiter] and which in ["both", "y"]:
471                    getattr(
472                        self[nameiter].get_yaxis().get_offset_text(),
473                        f"set_{key}",
474                    )(value)

def set_major_locator(self, locator: matplotlib.ticker.Locator, which: str = 'both'): 
476    def set_major_locator(
477        self,
478        locator: Locator,
479        which: str = "both",
480    ):
481        """
482        Sets the major locator for all of the axes.
483
484        Parameters
485        ----------
486        locator
487            the instance of `matplotlib.ticker.Locator` to use.
488
489        which : {'both', 'x', 'y'}
490            which axis to change (default: 'both')
491
492        Returns
493        -------
494        None
495
496        Raises
497        ------
498        EmptyFigureError
499            if `figure` is not set
500        """
501        if not self.figure:
502            raise EmptyFigureError
503
504        for nameiter in product(self.names, repeat=self._ndim):
505            # for some reason, we cannot reuse the same instance, so we just
506            # make a deep copy of it instead
507            if (
508                self[nameiter]
509                and np.any(self[nameiter].get_xticks())
510                and which in ["both", "x"]
511            ):
512                xloc = copy.deepcopy(locator)
513                self[nameiter].xaxis.set_major_locator(xloc)
514            if (
515                self[nameiter]
516                and np.any(self[nameiter].get_yticks())
517                and which in ["both", "y"]
518            ):
519                yloc = copy.deepcopy(locator)
520                self[nameiter].yaxis.set_major_locator(yloc)

def plot_curve_2d( fisher: fitk.tensors.FisherMatrix, name1: str, name2: str, ax: Optional[matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes] = None, scaling_factor: float = 1, **kwargs) -> tuple[matplotlib.figure.Figure, matplotlib.axes._axes.Axes, matplotlib.artist.Artist]: 
2328def plot_curve_2d(
2329    fisher: FisherMatrix,
2330    name1: str,
2331    name2: str,
2332    ax: Optional[Axes] = None,
2333    scaling_factor: float = 1,
2334    **kwargs,
2335) -> tuple[Figure, Axes, Artist]:
2336    r"""
2337    Plots a 2D curve (usually ellipse) from two parameters of a Fisher object.
2338
2339    Parameters
2340    ----------
2341    fisher : FisherMatrix
2342        the Fisher matrix which we want to plot
2343
2344    name1 : str
2345        the name of the first parameter which we want to plot
2346
2347    name2 : str
2348        the name of the second parameter which we want to plot
2349
2350    ax : matplotlib.axes.Axes, optional
2351        the axis on which we want to plot the contour (default: None). If None,
2352        plots to a new figure.
2353
2354    **kwargs
2355        any keyword arguments passed to `matplotlib.patches.Ellipse`
2356
2357    Returns
2358    -------
2359    A 3-tuple `(Figure, Axes, Artist)`
2360        The figure and the axis on which the artist was drawn on, as well as
2361        the artist itself.
2362
2363    Examples
2364    --------
2365    Define a Fisher matrix:
2366    >>> m = FisherMatrix(
2367    ... [[3, -2], [-2, 5]],
2368    ... names=['a', 'b'],
2369    ... fiducials=[1, -2],
2370    ... latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'],
2371    ... )
2372
2373    Draw the 1$\sigma$ contour of the parameter combination `a`, `b`:
2374    >>> fig, ax, artist = plot_curve_2d(m, name1='a', name2='b', ls='--', color='red', fill=False)
2375
2376    Rescale the view a bit:
2377    >>> _ = ax.autoscale()
2378    >>> _ = ax.relim()
2379    >>> _ = ax.autoscale_view()
2380
2381    Save it to a file:
2382    >>> fig.savefig(
2383    ... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "plot_curve_2d_example1.png",
2384    ... dpi=100)
2385
2386    <img width="100%" src="$IMAGE_PATH/plot_curve_2d_example1.png">
2387
2388    Notes
2389    -----
2390    The limits of the plot are not updated automatically.
2391    """
2392    if ax is None:
2393        _, ax = plt.subplots()
2394
2395    fidx = fisher.fiducials[np.where(fisher.names == name1)]
2396    fidy = fisher.fiducials[np.where(fisher.names == name2)]
2397
2398    a, b, angle = _get_ellipse(fisher, name1, name2)
2399
2400    patch = ax.add_patch(
2401        Ellipse(
2402            xy=(fidx, fidy),
2403            width=2 * a * scaling_factor,
2404            height=2 * b * scaling_factor,
2405            angle=angle,
2406            **kwargs,
2407        ),
2408    )
2409
2410    return (ax.get_figure(), ax, patch)

Plots a 2D curve (usually ellipse) from two parameters of a Fisher object.

Parameters
  • fisher (FisherMatrix): the Fisher matrix which we want to plot
  • name1 (str): the name of the first parameter which we want to plot
  • name2 (str): the name of the second parameter which we want to plot
  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes, optional): the axis on which we want to plot the contour (default: None). If None, plots to a new figure.
  • **kwargs: any keyword arguments passed to matplotlib.patches.Ellipse
Returns
  • A 3-tuple (Figure, Axes, Artist): The figure and the axis on which the artist was drawn on, as well as the artist itself.
Examples

Define a Fisher matrix:

>>> m = FisherMatrix(
... [[3, -2], [-2, 5]],
... names=['a', 'b'],
... fiducials=[1, -2],
... latex_names=[r'$\mathcal{A}$', r'$\mathcal{B}$'],
... )

Draw the 1$\sigma$ contour of the parameter combination a, b:

>>> fig, ax, artist = plot_curve_2d(m, name1='a', name2='b', ls='--', color='red', fill=False)

Rescale the view a bit:

>>> _ = ax.autoscale()
>>> _ = ax.relim()
>>> _ = ax.autoscale_view()

Save it to a file:

>>> fig.savefig(
... Path(__file__).parent.parent / os.environ.get("TEMP_IMAGE_DIR", "") / "plot_curve_2d_example1.png",
... dpi=100)

Notes

The limits of the plot are not updated automatically.
